titleStmt.title: The American remembrancer, and universal tablet of memory: containing a list of the most eminent men, whether in ancient or modern times, with the atchievements [sic] for which they have been particularly distinguished: as also the most memorable events in history, from the earliest period till the year 1795, classed under distinct heads, with their respective dates. : To which is added, a table, comprehending the periods at which the most remarkable cities and towns were founded, their present population, latitude, and longitude. : The whole being intended to form a comprehensive abridgement of history and chronology, particularly of that part which relates to America. / By James Hardie, A.M. ; [One line of Latin quotation]
titleStmt.author: Hardie, James, 1758-1826.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE AMERICAN REMEMBRANCER, AND Univer≈øal Tablet of Memory.

THE AMERICAN REMEMBRANCER, AND Univer≈øal Tablet of Memory: CONTAINING A LIST OF THE MOST EMINENT MEN, WHETHER IN ANCIENT OR MODERN TIMES, With the Atchievements for which they have been particularly di≈øtingui≈øhed: AS ALSO THE MOST MEMORABLE EVENTS IN HISTORY, From the earlie≈øt period till the year 1795, cla≈ø≈øed under di≈øtinct Heads, with their re≈øpective dates.
To which is added, A TABLE, COMPREHENDING THE PERIODS AT WHICH THE MOST REMARKABLE CITIES AND TOWNS WERE FOUNDED, THEIR PRESENT POPULATION, LATITUDE, AND LONGITUDE.

p.hi: The whole being intended to form a comprehen≈øive abridgement of Hi≈øtory and Chronology, particularly of that part which relates to America.

div.p: BY JAMES HARDIE, A. M.
PHILADELPHIA, PRINTED FOR THE AUTHOR BY THOMAS DOBSON, AT THE STONE-HOUSE, No 41, SOUTH SECOND-STREET. M.DCC.XCV.
Entered according to Act of Congre≈øs.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: TO pre≈øent, at one view, a ≈øeries of the mo≈øt remarkable events, tran≈øactions, and accidents which have occurred in ancient and modern times, and to tran≈ømit to po≈øterity the names and atchievements of great men, particularly of tho≈øe by who≈øe exertions, under Divine Providence, the United States enjoy their pre≈øent happy form of government, has been the principal de≈øign contemplated in the pre≈øent publication.

Through the whole of the following pages, the editor has ≈øelected his articles from hi≈øtorians of the fir≈øt rank, and from the mo≈øt authentic Annali≈øts; hence he hopes, that his performance will be found u≈øeful to every cla≈øs of readers‚ÄîTo the ≈øtudent it may frequently ≈øave the trouble of turning over a number of volumes to refre≈øh his memory; and to tho≈øe who≈øe lei≈øure cannot admit of the peru≈øal of many books, it may contain both entertainment and in≈øtruction. It will al≈øo be a remembrance to tho≈øe who have forgotten what they have read, and may ≈øerve as an epitome of univer≈øal hi≈øtory, particularly of that part which re≈øpects America.

To obviate the confu≈øion which would be occa≈øioned by blending all tran≈øactions, &c. together, the editor has cla≈ø≈øed the different ≈øubjects under ≈øeparate heads, each ranged in alphabetical order, which mode of arrangement he hopes will, in various re≈øpects, be found more convenient than the other.

Through every part of the work, the editor can with confidence a≈ø≈øert, that he has anxiou≈øly endeavoured to render the information contained as intere≈øting and accurate as po≈ø≈øible. Where he has ≈øailed in either of the≈øe re≈øpects, which he hopes has been ≈øeldom the ca≈øe, he ≈øolicits the indulgence of a candid public.

div.head: CONTENTS.

list.item: EMINENT men, with the atchievements for which they have been particularly di≈øtingui≈øhed, Page. 1
Inventions, improvements, and di≈øcoveries in the arts, &c. with the names of tho≈øe who have obtained patents for inventions and di≈øcoveries in the United States, Page. 48
Population, government, religion, &c. of the different continents, ≈øtates, empires, kingdoms, &c. Page. 119
Univer≈øities, colleges, and academies founded, Page. 126
Sea-fights, the mo≈øt remarkable, ≈øince the year 1300, Page. 156
Earthquakes, famines, inundations, ≈øtorms, tempe≈øts, fro≈øts, accidental fires, &c. Page. 193
The pre≈øent governors of the different ≈øtates, Page. 224

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: THE reader is reque≈øted to correct the following.
Page 6, for Boudinot Elias, read Bowdoin James,‚Äî and for New Brun≈øwick, read Brun≈øwick, Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts.

div.head: EMINENT MEN, WITH The Atchievements FOR WHICH THEY HAVE BEEN PARTICULARLY DISTINGUISHED.

div.p: AARON, the fir≈øt high prie≈øt of the Jews, was born 1570, and died 1453 before Chri≈øt.
Abel, born in the third year of the world, killed by Cain his brother 129 ditto.
Abercrombie General, defeated at Ticonderoga with great ≈ølaughter 1758.
Abraham, entertained three angels 1897, offered up his ≈øon I≈øaac 871; died 1821 before Chri≈øt, aged 175.
Achmet III. Emperor of the Turks, who encouraged printing in Con≈øtantinople, died 1730.
Adam, the fir≈øt man, died 3074 before Chri≈øt.

Adams John, of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, was one of tho≈øe patriots, who ≈øub≈øcribed the declaration of American Independence July 4, 1776: was cho≈øen by Congre≈øs to negociate a treaty of peace with Britain Sept. 25, 1779; appointed mini≈øter Plenipotentiary to the States General, January 1, 1781, with whom he concluded a treaty of amity and commerce October 8, 1782, ≈øub≈øcribed the Provi≈øional articles of peace, between Britain and the United States at Paris, November 30, following;
and the definitive treaty of peace September 3, 1783: ≈øub≈øcribed the treaty of amity and commerce with Pru≈ø≈øia Augu≈øt 5, 1785, being at that time mini≈øter at the court of Britain, where he wrote his defence of the con≈øtitution of the United States. On his return to his country, after ≈øo many important ≈øervices, he was elected Vice-Pre≈øident of the United States April 6, 1789, and now continues in that ≈øtation.

Adams, the patriotic Samuel, together with John Hancock, was by General Gage exempted from that pardon which by proclamation he promi≈øed to the other inhabitants of the colonies upon returning to their allegiance under the Briti≈øh king June 12, 1775: was elected Governor of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts upon the death of Governor Hancock 1794.
Addi≈øon Jo≈øeph, of England; author of the Spectators, Guardians, Poems and politics, died June 17, 1719.
Alexander Sir William, obtained, a charter for Nova Scotia Sept. 10, 1621, and afterwards ≈øold his right to the French 1630.
Alexander the Great, born 356; ≈øucceeded his father Philip 336; founded the Grecian empire 331; died at Babylon 323 years before Chri≈øt.
Alexander III. Pope, who compelled the kings of England and France to hold his ≈øtirrups, died 1181.

Alfred the Great, king of Britain, after ≈øubduing the Dani≈øh invaders, again≈øt whom he fought 56 battles by ≈øea and land, compo≈øed his body of laws, divided England into counties, &c. and ≈øhowed him≈øelf in every re≈øpect to be a wi≈øe and magnanimous prince; he died 899.
Allen, Colonel Ethan, of Vermont, took Ticonderoga May 10, 1775; was taken and put in irons by Sir Guy Carleton Sept. 25, 1775; publi≈øhed his Oracles of Rea≈øon 1786, and died 1788.
Almagro, created Governor of Chili 1536; quarrelled with Pizzarro 1537; by whom he was defeated and ≈øtrangled 1539, aged 75.
Amher≈øt General, took Loui≈øburgh 1758; Crown Point and Ticonderoga 1759.
Ananias and his wife Sapphira, ≈øtruck dead for fal≈øehood, 33.
Andre Major, taken by three New York militia-men, as he was returning from a conference with General Arnold at We≈øt Point, Sept. 27; and executed as a ≈øpy at Tapaan, Oct. 2, 1780.

Andros, Sir Edmund, Governor of New England, arrived at Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts 1686: after a tyrannical admini≈øtration of three years, he was ≈øeized by the people and ≈øent to Britain with 50 of his a≈ø≈øociates 1689.
Anker≈øtrom Captain, ≈øhot the king of Sweden, March 16, 1792; and was ≈øoon after beheaded.
An≈øon, the celebrated circumnavigator, died 1762, aged 62.
Antoniette Maria, Queen of France, was beheaded Oct. 16, 1793, aged 38.
Archimedes, the Mathematician, the inventor of the ≈øphere, was killed at Syracu≈øe 212 years before Chri≈øt.
Ari≈øtides the Grecian orator, lived 488 before Chri≈øt.
Ari≈øtotle, the Philo≈øopher, died at Calcide 322 before Chri≈øt, aged 63.

Arnold, General Benedict, commanded the American fleet on Lake Champlain, and was defeated by Sir Guy Carleton, Oct. 11, 1776. He bravely oppo≈øed the Briti≈øh at Ridgefield, Connecticut, April 27, 1777, and relieved fort Schuyler, de≈øerted to the Briti≈øh Sept. 20, 1780; invaded Virginia, January 5, 1781; de≈øtroyed New London and Groton, took fort Gri≈øwold, and put the garri≈øon to the ≈øword, Sept. 13, 1781.
A≈øcue Ann, a Prote≈øtant, was cruelly tortured by Henry VIII. of England, who to the di≈øgrace of royalty. put his own hands to the rack, not thinking the executioners ≈øufficiently expert, 1546.
A≈øh, Dr. Author of the Engli≈øh Dictionary, Grammar, &c. died April 1775, aged 55.
A≈øh General, was ≈øurpri≈øed in Georgia by General Prevo≈øt, when 152 of his men were killed and 162 made pri≈øoners, May 3, 1779.

Attabalipa, Emperor of Quito, defeated his brother, and u≈øurped the empire of Peru 1532: was ≈øeized by Pizarro, who extorted from him an immen≈øe ≈øum for his ran≈øom, and after a ≈øham trial put him to death 1533.
Atterbury Dr. Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, committed to the Tower Aug. 24, 1722; exiled May 27, 1723; died Feb. 22, 1732, aged 69.
Augu≈øtine, St. Father of the Latin church, born 354; baptized 387; died 431.
BACON Roger, of England, famous for his writings on natural philo≈øophy, died 1292.
Bacon Lord Ver ‚Ä¢ lam, of London, eminent for his writings on Natural Philo≈øophy and literature in general, died 1625.
Balchen Admiral, lo≈øt in the Victory man of war, Oct. 1744.
Barclay Robert, of Scotland, the author of the apology for the People called Quakers, catechi≈øm, &c. born 1640; died 1690.
Barclay Thomas, appointed to negociate a treaty of peace between the United States and the Emperor of Morocco, Oct. 11. 1785, concluded the treaty July 16, 1786.
Barlow Joel, of Connecticut, publi≈øhed his epic poem entitled "the Vi≈øion of Columbus," 1786; his Addre≈øs to the privileged orders of Europe, 1793.
Barre Colonel, made an eloquent ≈øpeech in the Briti≈øh parliament again≈øt the American Stamp-act, 1764.
Barrow, Rev. Dr. I≈øaac, of London, who wrote on natural philo≈øophy, mathematics; and al≈øo Sermons, died 1677, aged 46.
Ba≈økerville John, of Birmingham, the celebrated printer of the cla≈ø≈øics, died Jan. 18, 1775.
Baxter Andrew, of Old Aberdeen in Scotland, eminent for his writings on metaphy≈øics and natural philo≈øophy, died 1750.
Bayle of France, who wrote the hi≈øtorical and philo≈øophical dictionary, died 1723.

Baylor, Lieutenant-colonel of hor≈øe, ≈øurpri≈øed by the Briti≈øh at old Tapaan, New Jer≈øey, while his men were a≈øleep, and a mo≈øt barbarous ma≈ø≈øacre took place by order of the Briti≈øh General Gray, Sept. 27, 1778.
Beattie James, L L. D. of Aberdeen, celebrated for his e≈ø≈øay on the immutability of truth, and other metaphy≈øical writings, as al≈øo for his poetry, was alive 1794.
Beccaria Marquis, the author of a work on crimes and puni≈øhments, died in Maryland, Nov. 29, 1794.

Becket Thomas, made Chancellor to Henry II. 1157, Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury 1162: impeached 1164; when he retired to France; reconciled to Henry 1170: murdered in the Cathedral church, Dec. 29, 1170; cannonized by Pope Alexander III. on A≈øh-Wedne≈øday 1172.
Bede, a Prie≈øt of Northumberland, in England, who wrote the hi≈øtory of the Saxons, Scotch, &c. died 735
Bedford, Duke of, made a Regent of France 1422; died 1435.
Bellarmine, the celebrated defender of the doctrines of the Roman church, born in Italy 1542; died 1621.
Benedict, St. Founder of the Benedictines, died 546, aged 66 years.

Benezet Anthony, of benevolent memory, was born at St. Quintin in the province of Picardy in France, Jan. 31, 1713; arrived in Philadelphia Nov. 1731, and for ≈øome time followed mercantile bu≈øine≈øs; relinqui≈øhed merchandize, and became ≈øchoolma≈øter 1742: wrote many books again≈øt ≈ølavery and the African trade, and ≈øpent his la≈øt years in in≈øtructing the negroes. After a life ≈øpent in acts of con≈øtant benevolence, and having,
left his fortune to the ≈øupport of the African ≈øchool, he died May 36, 1784.
Bentley Rev. Doctor Richard, of York≈øhire in England, famous for his writings on cla≈ø≈øical learning and critici≈øm, was born 1662; and died 1742.
Berkeley, Bi≈øhop of Cloyne, celebrated for his writings on metaphy≈øics, died 1753, aged 73.
Bertholdus, who di≈øcovered gun powder, died 1340.
Beza Theodore, who tran≈ølated the New Te≈øtament into Latin, was born at Vezelai 1519 and died 1605.
Black≈øtone, Sir William, Judge of the court of common pleas, London, author of the Commentaries on the Laws of England, died Feb. 14, 1780.
Blair Hugh, D. D. of Edinburgh, who wrote lectures on rhetoric, and ≈øermons, was alive 1794.
Boadicea, Queen of the Britons, who burnt London and killed 70,000 of the inhabitants; poi≈øoned her≈øelf, 61.
Boerhaave, the celebrated Phy≈øician of Leyden, died Sept. 23, 1738, aged 69.
Boileau, the French poet, who wrote ≈øatires, epi≈øtles, art of poetry, tran≈ølations of Longinus, &c. was born 1630, and died 1712.
Bolinbroke Lord, of Surry in England, who wrote upon philo≈øophy, metaphy≈øics and politics, died 1751, aged 73.
Boudinot Elias, a member of Congre≈øs, gave 1000 l. (2666 dollars) to the college at New Brun≈øwick 1794.
Boulter, Archbi≈øhop of Armagh, in Ireland, who gave 30,000 l. Sterling (133,200 dollars) to charitable u≈øes, died 1742.
Bowdoin James, Governor of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, wrote on philo≈øophy and politics, and died 1785.
Boyer, the Lexicographer, was born 1664, died 1729.
Boyle, the honourable Robert, who wrote on natural and experimental philo≈øophy and theology, died 1691, aged 65.
Braddoc General, killed at Du Que≈øne, July 9, 1755.
Brahe Tycho, who invented a new ≈øolar ≈øy≈øtem, was born in Denmark 1546, and died 1601.

Bri≈ø≈øot de Warwille, a native of France, travelled through the United States 1788; and ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ after wrote an account of his travels. In all his writings, he appears to have been a friend to humanity. He was guillotined Oct. 30, 1794.
Brookey John, of Devon≈øhire in England, was alive in the year 1778, aged 135 years.
Brown Robert, founder of the ≈øect called the Browni≈øts, died 1630, aged 80.
Bruce James, the celebrated traveller and naturali≈øt, who vi≈øited the ≈øource of the Nile, and publi≈øhed an account of his travels, died at Kinnaird in Scotland 1794.
Brutus Junius, by who≈øe means the Roman government was changed from a monarchy to a republic, died 509 years before Chri≈øt.

Buchannan George, of Dumbarton≈øhire in Scotland, who wrote elegantly in latin the hi≈øtory of Scotland, tran≈ølated the P≈øalms of D ‚Ä¢ vid into Lyric poetry in the ≈øame language, and publi≈øhed a number of e≈ø≈øays on politics, &c. was born 1506, and died 1572.
Buffon, Count de, the celebrated naturali≈øt, a native of France, was born 1707 and died April 16, 1788.
Burgoyne, General, ≈øurrendered him≈øelf and his army as pri≈øoners of war to General Gates and the American forces, Oct. 17, 1777: died in London, 1793.
Burnet Gilbert, of Edinburgh, Bi≈øhop of Sarum, was born 1643, di≈øtingui≈øhed him≈øelf by his writings on hi≈øtory, biography, divinity, &c. died 1715.
Butler Samuel, of Worce≈øter in England, author of Hudibras, a burle≈øque poem, died 1680.
Byng, the Briti≈øh Admiral, accu≈øed of mi≈øconduct off Minorca, was ≈øhot at Spithead March 14, 1757.
CABOT Seba≈øtian, a native of Venice, who di≈øcovered North America in the year 1497, died 1557, aged 70.
Cae≈øar Julius, after fighting fifty pitched battles, ≈ølaying upwards of one milion of men and de≈øtroying the liberties of his country, was ≈ølain in the ≈øenate hou≈øe at Rome 44 before Chri≈øt.
Calvin, the founder of the Calvini≈øts, was born at Picardy in France 1506, and died at Geneva May 27, 1564.
Camden, William of England, di≈øtingui≈øhed by his hi≈øtory and antiquities, died 1623.
Campbell George, D. D. of Aberdeen in Scotland, who wrote a defence of the miracles of JESUS; tran≈ølation of the four Go≈øpels, &c. died 1793.

Carleton Sir Guy, was defeated at Longueil by Colonel Warner, Oct. 31, 1775; defeated Colonel Arnold on Lake Champlain Oct. 11, 1776; took command of the Royal forces at New York, May 5, 1782; evacuated New York, Nov. 25, 1783, was afterwards created an Engli≈øh peer, under the name of Lord Dorche≈øter, and appointed Governor of Canada.
Cave Edward, the compiler of the fir≈øt periodical magazine born 1691; and died 1754.
Caverley Sir Hugh, the fir≈øt per≈øon, who u≈øed guns for the ≈øervice of England, died 1389.
Caxton William, the fir≈øt who introduced into England, the art of printing by fu≈øile types, died 1494, aged 92.
Cervantes Michael, the author of Don Quixotte, &c. was born at Alcala in Spain, died 1620, aged 69.

Charlemagne, king of France, who began the Empire of Germany, afterwards called the We≈øtern Empire 800; gave the pre≈øent names to the winds and months, and endeavoured to re≈øtore learning in Europe, died 813, aged 70.
Charles I. king of England, was beheaded at London, Jan 30. 1649.
Chaucer, of London, commonly ≈øtyled the Father of Engli≈øh poetry, was born 1328, and died 1400.
Chauncey, Reverend Doctor, of Bo≈øton, who wrote a compleat view of Epi≈øcopacy, from the Fathers, Salvation for all men, Sermons, &c. died 1787.
Ch ‚Ä¢ ≈øterfield, Earl of, famous for his letters to his ≈øon and other writings, died 1773, aged 78.
Chri≈øtiana, Queen of Sweden, re≈øigned the crown June 6, 1654; and died at Rome, April 9, 1689.
Churchill, Rev. Charles, eminent for his ≈øatirical poems, was born 1731; died 1764.
Cibber Colley, born 1671; made Poet Laureat Dec. 1730; wrote 25 tragedies and comedies, and died 1757.
Cicero, the famous Roman Orator, was born 107: bani≈øhed 58, and put to death 43 years before Chri≈øt aged 64.

Cincinnatus Quintus, when his country was oppre≈ø≈øed, was taken from the plough to be Roman Dictator 458 before Chri≈øt: and after having procured peace to Rome, again returned to his rural employment.
Clar ‚Ä¢ ndon, See Hyde.
Clarke Colonel, made an expedition into the Indian country 1778; where he took the Lieutenant Governor of Detroit and the garri≈øon pri≈øoners.
Clarke, Reverend Doctor Samuel, of England, famous for his writings on mathematics, divinity, &c. died 1729.
Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt, killed her≈øelf 220 years before Chri≈øt, aged 41.
Clinton Sir Henry, arrived at Philadelphia and took command of the Royal forces May 8, 1778; took Charle≈øtown South Carolina, May 12, 1780; was ≈øuper≈øeded by Carleton, May 1782.

Clinton George, the fir≈øt Governor of New York after the revolution, by his exertions prevented the di≈øbandment of the American army, through want of bread
1780, continued Governor of that State till the year 1795, when he re≈øigned.
Clive Colonel, defeated the Nabob, June 26, 1757; created a Peer 1762; became in≈øane, and killed him≈øelf Nov. 1774, aged 49.
Clum, Mrs. near Lichfield in England, died Jan. 23, 1772, aged 138, and had lived 103 years in one hou≈øe.
Codrus, the la≈øt king of the Athenians, voluntarily gave his life for the good of his country, 1095 before Chri≈øt.
Coke, Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, who wrote on the laws of England, was born 1549, and died 1634.

Collyer, Sir George, took the American frigate Hancock, July 18, 1778; accompanied by General Mathews he made a de≈øcent on Virginia May 10, 1779; de≈øtroyed the American fleet at Penob≈øcot, Augu≈øt following.

Columbus Chri≈øtopher, a native of Genoa, after having in vain, made overtures to mo≈øt of the European princes, was at la≈øt enabled to ≈øet out on a voyage of di≈øcoveries by means of I≈øabella Queen of Spain 1492: ≈øet ≈øail Aug. 3, and di≈øcovered the i≈øland now called St. Chri≈øtophers, Oct. 11, 1492, ≈øailed for Spain Jan. 4, 1493: ≈øet out on his ≈øecond voyage Sept. 25, following; di≈øcovered great part of the We≈øt Indies, and returned to Spain 1496; ≈øailed on his third voyage May 3, 1498, and on Aug. 1, following, di≈øcovered the continent of America. By the machinations of his enemies, he was ≈øent home to Spain in Irons, Nov. 25, 1500. Having vindicated his conduct, he again ≈øet out on his fourth voyage May 9, 1502; made many important di≈øcoveries, and ≈øet out from Hi≈øpaniola for Spain, Sept. 12, 1504; died at Valad. ‚Ä¢ id May 20, 1506.

Calendar,
As many of our readers may be unacquainted with the French mode of reckoning time, we ≈øhall here ≈øubjoin their Calendar as regulated by the convention.
The year which con≈øi≈øts of twelve months, each month of three decades or thirty days commences on Sept. 22.

The intercalary day of every fourth year is called La Sans Cullotide; on which there is to be a national renovation of their oath, "to live free or die." The days of each decade are named from the Latin numerals thus, Primidi, Duodi, Tridi, Quatridi, Quintidi, Sextidi, Septidi, Oct ‚Ä¢ di, Nonodi and Decadi, which la≈øt is appointed as a day of re≈øt. the French adopted by the Convention 1793.

The Canal, which joins the Baltic and North Sea made open to all nations, May 14, 1785. From the forth to the Clyde in Scotland 1768. The Canal of Languedoc in France was begun 1666. It is extended over hills and vallies for 100 miles, opens a communication between the Mediterranean and the Ocean, and was compleated 1680.

Canal, the Grand, in Ireland, was begun 1756, and compleated from Dublin to Mona≈øtereven 1786. Canals in China, ≈øome of them are of an amazing extent, one in particular, reaching from Canton to Peking, being 1800 miles in length.

Eras, the mo≈øt remarkable in hi≈øtory. The Chri≈øtians make their era from the birth of Chri≈øt, which happened in the year of the world 3962. This was not u≈øed till about the year 600. The Mahometans compute their time from the Hegira; or flight of their prophet A. D. 617: The ancient Greeks reckoned by Olympiads, the fir≈øt of which is placed in the year of the world 3187; but as this account peri≈øhed under the Con≈øtantinopolitan Emperors, they reckoned by inductions, every induction containing 15 years, and the fir≈øt beginning A. D. 313. The ancient Romans reckoned from the building of their city, which was A. M 3113. The Jews had diver≈øe epochs or eras; fir≈øt, from the creation of the world 4004, before Chri≈øt; ≈øecondly from the univer≈øal deluge A. M. 1656: thirdly from
the confu≈øion of languages 1757, A. M. fourthly, from Abraham's journey to the land of Canaan 2021, A. M. fifthly, from the departure of the I≈øraelites out of Egypt 2513, A. M. ≈øixthly, from the year of the jubilee 2499: 7thly, from the building of Solomon's Temple 2932; and 8thly, from the captivity of Babylon 3357: The French era commenced Sept. 20, 1792, from which time they compute as follows: the ‚Äî year of the French republic one and indivi≈øible.

WATCHES, ≈øuppo≈øed to be invented at Nuremberg in Germany 1477; fir≈øt u≈øed in a≈øtronomical ob≈øervations by Purbech 1500: fir≈øt brought from Germ ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y to England 1597: invented with pendulums by Huygens of Zulichem 1657: ≈øpring pocket watches invented by Hooke 1658, an improvement in the con≈øtruction of watches by Robert Le≈ølie * of Philadelphia 1793.

Water mills, for grinding corn, invented by Belli≈øarius, while be≈øieged in Rome by the Goths 529. The ancients parched their corn and pounded it in mortars. Afterwards mills were invented, which were
turned by men and bea≈øts with great labour; and yet Pliny mentions wheels turned by water. For improvements in the con≈øtruction of water mills by Americans, ≈øee Mills.
Weaving duck, an improvement in, by James Davenport* of New Jer≈øey 1794.

Weights, and mea≈øures, invented 194 before Chri≈øt: fixed to a ≈øtandard in England 1257. A mode a≈øcertaining with certainty a ≈øtandard for weights and mea≈øures, according to Philo≈øophical principles, adopted by the French convention 1794.
Whales, killed at Newfoundland and Iceland for their oil only, 1578. As the u≈øe of their bones and fins were not known no ≈øtays were at that time worn by the Ladies.

Wild fire, commonly called Greek fire, was invented by Callinicus a Grecian 680. The u≈øe of this fire was continued by the Saracens again≈øt their enemies till the middle of the fourteenth century, when the ≈øcientific or ca≈øual compound of nitre, charcoal and ≈øulphur led to the di≈øcovery of gunpowder.
Wind guns, invented 1648: Wind mills 1299.
Windows of gla≈øs, were known as early as the third century, but did not become general in England till the year 1180.
Wine, the art of making it, fir≈øt di≈øcovered by Noah: ≈øold by apothecaries in England as a cordial 1300.
Wire, invented at Nuremberg 1410. Wire mills fir≈øt con≈øtructed in Germany 1563: a machine invented to weave wire by Timothy Kirk and Robert Le≈ølie * 1792.
Wool cards, invented by Bi≈øhop Blaize, about 300.

Woollen cloth, the fir≈øt made in England was 1331: at Sedan, in France 1646; at Hartford in Connecticut about 1787. An improvement in the art of ≈øhearing woollen and other cloth, invented by Samuel Kellogg,* of Vermont 1795.
Wormwood and other plants, u≈øed for pre≈øerving malt liquors before the u≈øe of Hops 1492.
Writing, the divine art of, ≈øuppo≈øed to be communicated by God to Mo≈øes, when he received the commandments on Mount Sinai 1491 before Chri≈øt.
YEAR, the ≈øolar, found to con≈øi≈øt of 365 days 5 hours and 49 minutes, 285 before Chri≈øt.
ZODIAC, the ≈øigns of, invented by Aneximander, about 540 before Chri≈øt.

div.head: Memorable Events.

div.p: ABBEY's and mona≈øteries, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by Henry VIII. of England, to the value of 12,667,520 Dollars 1540: ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by the Emperor of Germany 1785.
Abdication of King James II. of England, Dec. 1688; of Philip V. of Spain, January 1724; of Victor Amadaeus of Sardinia, Sept. 3, 1730.
Algiers, an in≈øurrection at, on account of tribute 1761.

Amba≈ø≈øador, the fir≈øt ≈øent from England to Turkey 1606; the fir≈øt who arrived in Europe from India, was from Tippo Saib to France, June 1788. George Hammond E≈øq the fir≈øt ≈øent from Britain to the United States 1791. Lord M'Cartney, the fir≈øt from England to China 1793.
Amboyna, the Engli≈øh factory at, murdered by the Dutch 1623.
America, the formerly Briti≈øh colonies of, declared independent by Congre≈øs, July 4, 1776. See United States.
Antioch, at, 100,000 people, killed by the Jews in one day 145 before Chri≈øt.
Antwerp, made a free port 1784.
Army, the American, much di≈øtre≈ø≈øed by famine and nakedne≈øs at Valley forge in the winter 1778.
A≈ø≈øociations.‚ÄîIn South Carolina, again≈øt the proprietary government, Nov. 28, 1719.
‚ÄîAgain≈øt the con≈øumption of Briti≈øh manufactures in ≈øeveral of the colonies 1764.
‚ÄîAgain≈øt the ≈øtamp act, by the New York and Connecticut ≈øons of liberty, Dec. 25, 1766.
‚ÄîAgain≈øt importing goods from Britain, till the ≈øtamp act ≈øhould be repealed, by the merchants in New York, Oct. 31, 1766.
‚ÄîBy the merchants in Philadelphia, Nov. 7, 1766, and about the ≈øame time by the merchants of Bo≈øton.
‚ÄîBy the Virginians, again≈øt importing any goods from Britain, which were taxed, May 18, 1769.
‚ÄîBy the Gentlemen and merchants of Maryland, June 1769.

‚ÄîIn South Carolina the ≈øame year; when the city of Charle≈øtown, broke off all commerce with Rhode I≈øland and Georgia, becau≈øe they had not adopted ≈øimilar mea≈øures with their ≈øi≈øter colonies. Georgia acceeded to the non-importation agreement. Sept. 19, 1769, and North Carolina the October following.
Ba≈øtille, the French, taken July 14, 1789.

Bo≈øton, port bill pa≈ø≈øed by the Briti≈øh parliament, March 25, 1774; by which act that port was to continue ≈øhut, from and after June 1, next en≈øuing, till full ≈øatisfaction ≈øhould be made to the Ea≈øt India company, for their tea de≈øtroyed.
Bottle conjuror, who had given out that he would jump into a quart bottle, impo≈øed on the credulous multitude, at the Haymarket theatre London, Jan. 16, 1748.
Bottle, which contained two hog≈øheads, was blown at Leith in Scotland, Jan. 7, 1747.
Bull and three heifers, the fir≈øt creatures of that kind, in New England, were brought to Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts 1624.
CASTLES, demoli≈øhed in England, to the number of 1100, in 1153.

Cen≈øus, of the inhabitants of the United States, was taken by act of Congre≈øs in the year 1790: when the whole number was found to be 3,929,326, of whom in the≈øe free ≈øtates there were 697,655 ≈ølaves.
Ceylon, nearly de≈øtroyed by the natives, to revenge the cruelties of the Dutch 1761.
Child, the fir≈øt born of European parents, in New England, Nov. 1620.
Colo≈ø≈øus, of Rhodes, thrown down, 234 before Chri≈øt. It weighed 713,000 lb.
Colony, the fir≈øt Engli≈øh in America, planted on the i≈øland of Roanoke in Virginia 1585.
Commemoration of Handel, the fir≈øt, performed in We≈øtmin≈øter abbey, by 600 performers, May 26, 1784.
Commi≈ø≈øioners to the court of France, appointed by Congre≈øs, Sept. 26, 1776.
Commi≈ø≈øioners re≈øolved by Congre≈øs, to be ≈øent to the courts of Vienna, Madrid, Pru≈ø≈øia and Tu≈øcany, Dec. 28, 1776.

Commi≈ø≈øioners, viz. William Eden, George John≈øtone, and the Earl of Carli≈øle, appointed by the court of Britain to treat with America, arrive at Philadelphia, June 1778; with whom Congre≈øs refu≈øe to treat unle≈øs their independence ≈øhould be admitted, or the Briti≈øh fleets and armies withdrawn.

Commi≈ø≈øioners from ≈øeveral States, agreeably to the recommendation of James Madi≈øon of Virginia, met at Annapolis Maryland, for the purpo≈øe of effecting a more efficient government for the United States, 1786.
Confederation articles of, for mutual defence agreed upon by the four New England colonies, 1643.
Confederation articles of, and perpetual union agreed on between the American colonies, May 20, 1775.
Confederation at Paris, in commemoration of the capture of the Ba≈øtille, July 14, 1790.
Congre≈øs a, met at New York, to con≈øult on mea≈øures nece≈ø≈øary to be taken for the mutual a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and defence of the colonies, May 1, 1690.
Congre≈øs a, of Governors met at New London, to adju≈øt the mea≈øures nece≈ø≈øary to be taken for the Canada expedition 1711.
Congre≈øs a, met at Albany, to concert a plan for the union of all the colonies 1754.
Congre≈øs a, met at New York, to con≈øult upon mea≈øures for obtaining the redre≈øs of grievances 1765.

Congre≈øs the, met at Philadelphia, Sept. 5, 1774: di≈ø≈øolved Oct. 26, following; met again at Philadelphia, May 10, 1775: ≈øigned a petition to the king, and addre≈ø≈øed the inhabitants of Britain and Ireland, July 8, 1775: aboli≈øhed the authority of Britain over the then colonies, May 15, 1776; and on July 4, following; declare the colonies to be free, ≈øovereign and independent, under the name of the United States.
The following, is a li≈øt of tho≈øe patriots who ≈øub≈øcribed this important in≈øtrument, viz.
JOHN HANCOCK, PRESIDENT.
New Hamp≈øhire, Jo≈øiah Bartlett, William Whipple, Mathew Thornton.
Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts Bay, Samuel Adams, John Adams, Robert Treat Paine, Eldridge Gerry.
Rhode I≈øland, Stephen Hopkins, William Ellery.
Connecticut, Roger Sherman, Samuel Huntington, William Williams. Oliver Wolcott.
New York, William Floyd, Philip Living≈øton, Francis Lewis, Lewis Morris
New Jer≈øey, Richard Stockton, John Wither≈øpoon, Francis Hopkin≈øon, John Hart, Abraham Clark.
Penn≈øylvania, Robert Morris, Benjamin Ru≈øh, Benjamin Franklin, John Morton, George Clymer, James Smith, George Taylor, James Wil≈øon, George Ro≈øs.
Delaware, Cae≈øar Rodney, George Read, Thomas M'Kean.
Maryland, Samuel Cha≈øe, William Paca, Thomas Stone, Charles ‚Ä¢ arroll of Carleton.
Virginia, George Wythe, Richard Hen ‚Ä¢ y Lee, Thomas Jeffer≈øon, Benjamin Harri≈øon, Thomas Nel≈øon, junior, Francis Lightfoot Lee, Carter Braxton.
North Carolina, William Hooper, Jo≈øeph Hewes, John Pen ‚Ä¢ .
South Carolina, Edward Rutledge, Thomas Heyward, junior, Thomas Lynch, junior, Arthur Middleton.
Georgia, Button Gwinnett, Lyman Hall, George Walton.
Congre≈øs, fir≈øt meeting of under the federal con≈øtitution at New York, March 4, 1789, met at Philadelphia, Dec. 6, 1790.
Con≈øpiracies, in≈øurrections, and a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinations, the mo≈øt remarkable in ancient or modern hi≈øtory:

A con≈øpiracy, was formed again≈øt the infant republic of Rome, to re≈øtore Sextus Tarquin, and the regal government, in which the two ≈øons of Junius Brutus, the fir≈øt con≈øul, being concerned, were condemned and put to death by order of their father, 507 before Chri≈øt; con≈øpiracy of Cataline and his a≈ø≈øociates, to murder the con≈øul and Roman ≈øenate, and to burn the city of Rome, di≈øcovered by Cicero con≈øul for that year 62; of the Gunpowder plot in England, which was di≈øcovered Nov. 4, 1605; of the Bi≈øhop of Ely and others to re≈øtore king James 1691; of Lord Lovat in favour of the pretender 1703; of Layer and others to bring in the pretender 1722; at Li≈øbon, by ≈øeveral of the nobility who attempted to ≈øhoot the king 1758; at Madrid, when the king was obliged to bani≈øh the Marquis Squillaci 1769; by five Frenchmen to kill the king of Spain, after which all Frenchmen were expelled the Spani≈øh dominions, 1793. The unfortunate victims of this mandate, were ≈øaid to be upwards of 70,000; of Anker≈øtrom, who killed Gu≈øtavus III. king of Sweden, March 16, 1792; an attempt to a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinate Louis XV. was made by Francis Damien 1757; an attempt to a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinate the king of Poland by Thorin≈øki, Pula≈øki and others, Sept. 3, 1771; to a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinate George III. by Margaret Nichol≈øon, a lunatic, Augu≈øt 2, 1786.

Con≈øpiracies and in≈øurrections in America: of the Indians in New England to de≈øtroy the coloni≈øts, di≈øcovered by John Segamore a friendly Indian, April 1630; of Cleybourne and Ingle, again≈øt the Governor of Maryland, who fled to Virginia 1645, and could not return till the month of Aug. 1646; of Culpepper again≈øt the proprietary government of Carolina, which commenced 1677, and continued till 1680: again in the year 1690; of the negroes at Stono in South Carolina, who committed great depredations again≈øt the inhabitants 1738; of Shays, and others in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts 1786; of the negroes in St. Domingo, which commenced
Aug. 1791, and is not yet ≈øuppre≈ø≈øedThe negroes, had been inhumanly treated by their tyrannical ma≈øters. The word in≈øurrection, is therefore in this in≈øtance, perhaps too har≈øh.; of the four We≈øtern counties of Penn≈øylvania, which though at fir≈øt very alarming, was by the prudence of the pre≈øident and the patrioti≈øm of the militia, quelled without blood≈øhed, 1794. In North Carolina, when a body of people under the name of regulators, headed by Herman Hu≈øband, began to oppo≈øe government 1770. They were at la≈øt ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by the friends of order in an engagement, where they lo≈øt 20 men killed and a number wounded, 12 of the leaders were capitally convicted and ≈øix executed; Hu≈øband e≈øcapedNow in Philadelphia jail, charged with high trea≈øon in the late in≈øurrection, in the We≈øtern counties of Penn≈øylvinia.. Of the Corce and Tu≈øcorora Indians, who killed upwards of 150 inhabitants of North Carolina 1712.

Con≈øtitution the Federal, agreed to by the grand convention held at Philadelphia, by a repre≈øentation from 21 States, (Rhode I≈øland not being repre≈øentated, Sept. 17, 1787; ratified by the different States in the follownig order.
Kentucky, received into the union, June 1, 1792.
Con≈øtitution, the fir≈øt French, pre≈øented to the king, Sept. 3, 1791; the new con≈øtitution after the abolition of royalty, adopted by the convention, June 23, 1793.

Convention, the Federal, met at Philadelphia, for the purpo≈øe of forming a new con≈øtitution for the United States, May 25, 1787.
The members of this honourable body, were as follow
GEORGE WASHINGTON, Pre≈øident and delegate from Virginia.
New Hamp≈øhire, John Langdon, John Gilman.
Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, Nathaniel Gorham, Rufus King.
Connecticut, William Samuel John≈øon, Roger Sherman.
New York, Alexander Hamilton.
New Jer≈øey, William Living≈øton, David Brearly, William Patter≈øon, Jonatha ‚Ä¢ Dayton.
Penn≈øylania, Benjamin Franklin, Thomas Mifflin, Robert Morris, George Clymer, Thomas Fit≈øimmons, Jared Inger≈øol, James Wil≈øon, Governeur Morris.
Delaware, George Read, Gunning Bedford, junior, John Dickin≈øon, Richard Ba≈ø≈øett, Jacob Broom
Maryland, James M'Henry, Daniel of St. Thomas, Jennifer, Daniel Carroll.
Virginia, John Blair, James Madi≈øon, junior.
North Carolina, William Blount, Richard Dobbs Spaight, Hugh William≈øon.
South Carolina, John Rutledge, Charles Cate≈øworth, Pinckney, Charles Pinckney, Pierce Butler.
Georgia, William Few, Abraham Baldwin.
Conventions, in ≈øeveral towns in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, were held for the purpo≈øe of redre≈ø≈øing grievances 1784, which laid the foundation of the in≈øurrection which took place 1786.
Convention the French, fir≈øt a≈ø≈øembled Sept. 20, 1792. The legi≈ølative body of France, previous to that meeting was called the National A≈ø≈øembly.
Convention the Iri≈øh, for the reform of parliament met at Dublin, Dec. 8, 1785.
Cook, Captain James, circumnavigated the globe 1776.
DRAKE Sir Francis, circumnavigated the globe 1580.

Duel, the fir≈øt fought in New England, was between two ≈øervants with ≈øword and dagger, when neither of them being killed, the puni≈øhment inflicted on them was to have their feet and heads tied together, and kept in that ≈øituation 24 hours without meat or drink 1621.
ELLIN Ellis, at Beaumaris in Denbigh≈øhire England, aged 72, was brought to bed, May 10, 1766.
FAST a, ob≈øerved throughout the American colonies, June 1, 1774, being the day on which the Bo≈øton portbill took effect.

France, admitted American independence, Feb. 6, 1778; the court gave an audience to the American commi≈ø≈øioners, viz. Me≈ø≈øieurs Franklin, Deane and Lee, March 21, 1778; the French recovered their civil liberty, July 14, 1789.
GENOA Bank, ≈øailed 1750.
Great ≈øeal, ≈øtolen from the Lord Chancellor of Britain, March 24, 1784.
HABEAS corpus act, ≈øu≈øpended in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts during the in≈øurrection of 1786; in Britain 1794.
Hair, an a≈ø≈øociation again≈øt wearing it long, by the Governor and council of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, who con≈øidered it as a heinous ≈øin, March 1649.
He≈ø≈øian fly, ≈øee Wheat In≈øect.
Holland, allows the American independence, April 19, 1782.
Hol≈øtein, ceded to Denmark by Ru≈ø≈øia 1773.
Hugenots, murdered at Paris, Aug. 24, 1572.
INQUISITION of Naples, aboli≈øhed 1782.
In≈øurrection, ≈øee Con≈øpiracy.
Ireland, admitted to a free trade by the Briti≈øh parliament 1779: its liberty of the pre≈øs re≈øtrained 1784.
JERSEY, the Briti≈øh pri≈øon ≈øhip, during the American war 11,000 pri≈øoners peri≈øhed on board of her, from ill treatment.

LADIES, the patriotic of Philadelphia, with their own donations purcha≈øe a quantity of linen, which with their own hands they made into 1207 ≈øhirts, for the u≈øe of the American army, July and Augu≈øt 1780; the ladies of New Jer≈øey, at the ≈øame time made a pre≈øent of 380 pairs of ≈øtockings; the whig ladies of Charle≈øtown, South Carolina, ab≈øolutely refu≈øed any ≈øociality with the Briti≈øh; while they generou≈øly contributed to mitigate the ≈øufferings of the American pri≈øoners 1781.
League and covenant, the ≈øolemn for (as it was ≈øtated) the reformation and defence of religion, formed at We≈øtmin≈øter 1643: ratified by the Scotch parliament 1644.

League and covenant, a ≈øolemn, entered into by the Bo≈øton committee, to ≈øu≈øpend all commercial intercour≈øe with Britain, from Aug. 31, 1774, until the Bo≈øton port-bill and all other obnoxious laws ≈øhould be repealed.
Liberty of the pre≈øs, granted in Denmark 1770.
Longevity, extraordinary in≈øtances of it in England. Thomas Parr, of Shrop≈øhire, died 1635, aged 160; Henry Jenkins of York≈øhire, died 1670, aged 169.

Longevity in America 1765, Mr. Temple of Worce≈øter Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, aged 86 left 8 Children, who≈øe
ages in 1790, were as follow, viz. 89, 85, 83, 81, 79, 77, 75, 73. John Sydenham, of Mount Holly, New Jer≈øey, was living N ‚Ä¢ v. 5, 1788, aged 106 years and 3 months; Edward Drinker, born in Philadelphia, died 1782, aged 102 years; Mr Hutton, died on Long I≈øland, New York 1794, aged 108 years; In the bills of mortality of Chri≈øt Church Philadelphia, there is a per≈øon mentioned, who died aged 120. In two hundreds of Sommer≈øet county, Maryland 1793, there were fifty per≈øons aged as follow, twenty three upwards of 90, 16 upwards of 87, and 11 aged 85 years. In 1775, Mrs. Lear, died at Port≈ømouth New Hamp≈øhire, aged 103, Mr. Abigail Mayo, in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts aged 106, and Mr. William Ward, at Fairfield in Connecticut, aged 105: Sept. 20, 1788, in Albemaric county, Virginia, Daniel Manphin, died in his 88th year. At the time of his death, there were living of his offspring upwards of 200 per≈øons including ≈øome of the fifth generation. Same year Jacob Wi≈øeman, died in Penn≈øylvania, aged 103, and left living 170 of his de≈øcendants; Mr Williams at Che≈øterfield, Virginia aged 105: at Wyndham in Connecticut, Dr. Ribbins, aged 110: John Dance Che≈øterfield county, Virginia, aged 125. In 1790, died Doctor Bernard Vanlear, in Delaware county, aged 104: In Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, Mrs. Newton, aged 106: her mother lived to 113, and her ≈øi≈øter to 102. At Thomp≈øon, Connecticut, Henry Elthrop, aged 105. At Albany, Abraham Vanverts, aged 124.The≈øe remarks, which are extracted from the writings of the celebrated Doctor Ru≈øh, in≈øerted in the tran≈øactins of the American Philo≈øophical ≈øociety, will clearly ≈øatisfy the unprejudiced reader that the chance for a long life is as great in America, as in any country of Europe. As a further proof of this truth the following fact may be added. In the Lutheran congregation of Philadelphia, the births between the years 1774, and 1780, were 5175, and the deaths only 2380. William Taylor, in Pitt county Virginia, died aged 114, 1794.
Marriage, the fir≈øt Engli≈øh, celebrated in New England, May 12, 1621.

Ma≈ø≈øacres, horrid 2000 Tyrians crucified, and 8000 put to the ≈øword, for not ≈øurrendering to Alexander the Great, 331 before Chri≈øt. The Jews of Antioch ma≈ø≈øacred, 100,000 of the other inhabitants for refu≈øing to ≈øurrender their arms to Demetrius Nicanor, tyrant of Syria 145. About 200,000 of the Teutones and Ambrones, were ma≈ø≈øacred by order of Marius the Roman General near Aix 102; 300 Roman ≈øenators and other per≈øons of di≈øtinction, were ≈øacrificed to the manes of Julius Cae≈øar by order of Sylla 41. At the de≈øtruction of Jeru≈øalem, 1,000,000 Jews were ma≈ø≈øacred A. D. 70. The Emperor Probus, after he had ≈øubdued Gaul, ma≈ø≈øacred 700,000 inhibitants, 277. At The≈ø≈øalonica, upwards of 7000, per≈øons invited into the circus, were ma≈ø≈øacred by order of Theodo≈øius 390. At Con≈øtantinople 30,000 inhabitants were put to death by order of Bel ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ arius, becau≈øe they had revolted again≈øt the oppre≈ø≈øion of two rapacious mini≈øters, ≈øet over them by the emperor Ju≈øtinian 532. The dreadful ma≈ø≈øacre of the French, without di≈øtinction of age or ≈øex, in Sicily on Ea≈øter day 1282. This is called the Sicilian ve≈øpers;; of 70,000 Hugeno ‚Ä¢ s in France, which began at Paris in the night of the Fe≈øtival of St. Bartholomew, Augu≈øt 25, 1572, by orders from Charles IX. of France, at the in≈øtigation of his infamous mother, Catharine de Medicis. Of 65,000 Chri≈øtians, ≈ølain by the Turks in Croatia 1592, of the Engli≈øh, by the Dutch at Amboyna 1624; of the Iri≈øh in different parts of that kingdom when 40,000 were ≈ølain‚ñ™ In Paris, Sept. 2, and 3, 1793, when ≈øtate pri≈øoners, amounting to the number of 1085, were ma≈ø≈øacred by the populace ≈øuppo≈øed to be excited by Marat, Robe≈øpiere and Danton; of the Ru≈ø≈øian General Suwarrow, who butchered 20,000 Polanders near War≈øaw, Nov. 4. 1794, of the
Spaniards, who by their cruelties depopulated the i≈ølands of Cuba, containing 600,000 and Hi≈øpaniola 3,000,000 of inhabitants, about the year 1510; the Yama≈ø≈øee Indians ma≈ø≈øacre a number of the inhabitants of South Carolina, April 15, 1714; a ma≈ø≈øacre of the Virginians by the Indians, 1644; of Indians by the Penn≈øylvanians, 1764; of the Bo≈øtonians by the Briti≈øh 29th regiment, March 5, 1770; by the Briti≈øh near Paoli, Che≈øter county, September 11, 1777; at Wyoming, of the Americans by the Indians and Tories, July 1, 1778; at Taapan of 67 Americans by order of General Gray, September 27, 1778; of the Moravian Indians at Mu≈økingum by a party of Americans, when 90 were inhumanly butchered in the ≈øpring of 1782; at Fort Dauphin, St. Domingo, when the Spaniards murdered 742 Frenchmen, July 7, 1794.
Mi≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øippi bubble, in France, cea≈øed June 27, 1720.
Mob, ≈øee riot.

Mohocks, a ≈øet of di≈øorderly people, infe≈øted the ≈øtreets of London at night, wounding and disfiguring the men and indecently expo≈øing the women 1711, when the executive i≈ø≈øued a proclamation offering a reward of 444 Dollars for apprehending each of them.
Monarchy aboli≈øhed in France, September 20, 1792.

NATIONAL A≈ø≈øembly of France fir≈øt met May 5, 1789; on the 17th June following the Tiers etats or repre≈øentatives of the people, after u≈øing every effort to obtain an union with the privileged orders, con≈øtituted them≈øelves the National A≈ø≈øembly.
Non importation, non con≈øumption, and non exportation agreement entered by the merchants in the different colonies, December 14th, 1774.
North We≈øt pa≈ø≈øage, attempted by Captain Phipps, now Lord Mu≈øgrave, 1773.
OXFORD a≈ø≈øizes, in England, made memorable by the death of the Sheriff and 300 per≈øons, who died of the goal di≈øtemper caught from the pri≈øoners 1577.
PACKET a, of blank paper, was received by Congre≈øs from Paris, in≈øtead of the di≈øpatches from their Amba≈ø≈øadors there, June 12th, 1778.

Paper money, fir≈øt made in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts 1690; emitted by Rhode I≈øland 1744; by Penn≈øylvania 1722; i≈ø≈øued by Congre≈øs May 15th, 1775; made a legal tender 1777; after a gradual depreciation, cea≈øed to circulate without occa≈øioning any di≈øturbance, 1781.
Per≈øian army, fearing they ≈øhould be cut off by the Romans, threw them≈øelves into the Euphrates, where upwards of 10,000 peri≈øhed, 424.
Peter, Emperor of Ru≈ø≈øia, vi≈øited England, 1698.
Poland, di≈ømantled of ≈øeveral of its provinces by Ru≈ø≈øia, Pru≈ø≈øia, and the Emperor of Germany, 1772; hara≈ø≈øed again by the ≈øame powers 1794.
Pope the, vi≈øited Vienna, to ≈øolicit the Emperor in favour of the Roman church, March 1782.
Powell, a lawyer, walked from London to York and back again in ≈øix days, November 27, 1773, about 402 miles. He again performed the ≈øame journey June 20, 1787, when aged 57.
Printing pre≈øs, ≈øet up at Cambridge, New England, 1642; practi≈øed at Con≈øtantinople 1730; aboli≈øhed 1740; re-e≈øtabli≈øhed 1784.

Proclamations remarkable, General Gage's, promi≈øing pardon to all who would lay down their arms, June 12, 1775; Lord and General Howe's to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, Novr. 30, 1776; Burgoyne'sOur readers may compare the ga≈øconading proclamations of Burgoyne and Brun≈øwick with that of Senacherib mentioned in the Bible, 2 Kings xviii. and xix. chapters. May all crack-brained generals, meet with a fate ≈øimilar to that of the≈øe three bullies. threatning proclamation,
June 29, 1777; Tryone's to the inhabitants of Connecticut, July 7, 1778; a proclamation made in Paris "that the country was in danger," July 22, 1792; the ≈øanguinary proclamation of the Duke of Brun≈øwick again≈øt the French, July 25, 1792; of the Pre≈øident of the United States, recommending neutrality, April, 1793.
QUAKERS, began to be per≈øecuted in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, 1656; a committee from their yearly meeting pre≈øented an addre≈øs to Congre≈øs again≈øt ≈ølavery, March, 1790.
Queens of England, Scotland, and France, in England at the ≈øame time, 1517.
REVOLT, of the Penn≈øylvania and part of the New Jer≈øey line of troops, January 9, 1781: they were, however, ≈øoon after reconciled to their duty.

Revolutions remarkable, in ancient hi≈øtory, the A≈ø≈øyrian empire de≈øtroyed, and that of the Medes and Per≈øians founded by Cyrus the Great, 536 B. C.; the Per≈øian empire de≈øtroyed by Alexander the Great, and the Macedonian ≈øucceeds, 331 B. C.; the Roman empire e≈øtabli≈øhed on the ruins of the Macedonian, or Greek monarchy by Julius Cae≈øar, 47 B. C.; the ea≈øtern empire founded by Con≈øtantine the Great, on the final overthrow of the Romans, A. D. 306; the empire of the we≈øtern Franks, began under Charlemagne A. D. 802; this empire underwent a new revolution and became the German empire under Rudolph of Aug≈øburg, 1273, head of the hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, from whom it is al≈øo called "the monarchy of the Au≈øtrians;" the monarchy of the Ea≈øtern empire, pa≈ø≈øed into the hands of the Turks, A. D. 1353.

Revolutions, in modern hi≈øtory, in Denmark, January 1661, when the king became ab≈øolute; in Sweden, Augu≈øt, 1772, when the power of the king was greatly augmented; revolution began in Holland, 1579, and was completed, 1609; in Britain, when James VI. having abdicated the throne, William, Prince of Orange ≈øucceeded, 1688; in Poland, May, 1791This con≈øtitution was, univer≈øally, believed to be well calculated to remove the inveterate evils, under which, the unhappy Poles had for a long time laboured; but, by the very forcible rea≈øoning of the bayonet, employed by the humane empre≈øs of Ru≈ø≈øia, it has been ≈øince overturned.; revolution in America began July 4, 1776, and was completed, September, 1783, when its independence was acknowledged by the king of Britain; in Holland a revolution was attempted, 1787, but prevented by Pru≈ø≈øia; the revolution in France may be ≈øaid to have commenced on the capture of the Ba≈øtille, July 14, 1789; royalty declared by the Convention to be for ever aboli≈øhed in France, September, 1792; revolution in Holland, January, 1795.

Riots remarkable, in London of the Whig and Tory mobs, commonly called from their leaders, the Ormond and New Ca≈øtle mobs, immediately after the acce≈ø≈øion of George I. 1715: both parties having done much mi≈øchief, what is called the riot act was pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øame year; rioters in Hereford≈øhire, demoli≈øhed the turnpikes and were quelled after a ≈øevere engagement with the po≈ø≈øe comitatus, 1735; of the Spittal-field weavers, on account of their employers having ≈øent for workmen from Ireland, when the military interfered and ≈øeveral lives were lo≈øt, 1736; at Edinburgh, the pri≈øon door was ≈øet fire to by the populace, and a Captain Porteous (who had wantonly ordered his ≈øoldiers to fire upon the people at a former mob, for which he had beeen ju≈øtly condemned and afterwards reprieved) was taken out and hanged on a ≈øign po≈øt, 1736; the people peaceably retired immediately after his death; of the people in all parts of England, on account of the dearth of provi≈øions, 1766 and 1767; a mob having
a≈ø≈øembled in St. George's fields, London, to ≈øee John Wilkes in the King's-Bench pri≈øon, the military being imprudently called for, fired upon the populace and killed ≈øeveral innocent per≈øons, 1768; a great riot in London, June 6, 1780, when a number of Roman chapels, pri≈øons, and private hou≈øes, were de≈øtroyed by the mob; the military were at la≈øt called and fired upon the populace, when many were killed, and many more afterwards executed for f ‚Ä¢ lony; a dreadful riot in Paris, when 600 people were killed before it was ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, April 27, 1789; at Paris again, between the national guards and ≈øome royal companies who had a≈ø≈øumed the white cockade, when 24 of the latter were killed, June 4, following; at the palace of the Thuillieries, to compel the king to withdraw his veto from the decree again≈øt the prie≈øts, &c. June 20, 1792; in Ireland, riots of the White Boys, 1786; of the Peep of day Boys, 1789;

RiotsHappily for this country, the peaceable di≈øpo≈øition of the inhabitants; the fertility of the ≈øoil; and the excellence of the government, render the people ea≈øy and comfortable in their ≈øituation: hence there being few grounds of complaints, riots, mobs, and in≈øurrections ≈øeldom happen, and the≈øe few have been ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed with little or no blood≈øhed. in America, general, through all the colonies, on account of the Stamp Act, when tho≈øe who were in favour of that unpopular mea≈øure, were burnt in effigy by the populace, 1765; in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, to prevent the ≈øitting of the court at Worce≈øter, 1786; of 400 men, who wi≈øhed to force the legi≈ølature of New Hamp≈øhire, into a paper money ≈øy≈øtem, 1786; of a number of di≈øbanded ≈øoldiers, to the amount of 300, who wanted to force Congre≈øs to redre≈øs their grievances, June 20, 1783; an alarming riot in New York again≈øt the young phy≈øicians, whom the mob accu≈øed of taking up for di≈ø≈øection a number of dead bodies; ≈øeveral of the mob were killed by the militia before the riot was ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, 1787.
Roman ladies, a number having murdered their hu≈øbands, 170 ≈øuffered death for it: this was the fir≈øt example of ≈øuch a crime, 331.
Ru≈ø≈øia, acknowledged the independence of the United States, July, 1783.
SAMPSON, pulled down the temple of Dagon and de≈øtroyed 3000 Phili≈øtines, 1117 before Chri≈øt.
South Sea ≈øcheme, which ruined ≈øeveral hundred families, vani≈øhed in England, 1720.

Straw, u≈øed for the Engli≈øh king's bed, 1234.

Style, altered by Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar's ordering leap year to be but once in four years, and the month Sextilis to be called Augu≈øt, eight years before Chri≈øt; it was again altered by Pope Gregory, in Italy, the 5th October being accounted the 15th, 1582; the Gregorian ≈øtyle was adopted by France, December 15, following; by mo≈øt of the Prote≈øtant ≈øtates in Europe, 1700; by Britain, when the 3d of September was accounted the 14th, 1752;
Sweden, acknowledged the independence of the United States, February 25, 1783.

TEA, a quantity belonging to the Briti≈øh Ea≈øt India company con≈øi≈øting of 340 che≈øts was de≈øtroyed by the populace at Bo≈øton, to expre≈øs their abhorrence of Briti≈øh taxes, and 17 che≈øts were de≈øtroyed at New York for the ≈øame rea≈øon, November, 1773.

Torture, aboli≈øhed in France by edict of Louis the la≈øt king, Augu≈øt 29, 1780; by the late king of Sweden, November 22, 1785: in Poland, 1776.
Trade with the American colonies, prohibited by the Briti≈øh parliament, Augu≈øt 18, 1775.

thirteen ≈øtripes alternately red and white and thirteen ≈øtars in a blue field, June 20, 1777; their independence was admitted by France, February 6, 1778; by Britain, 1782; and ≈øoon after by the other powers of Europe.
WALES, a prince of, committed to pri≈øon for a≈ø≈øaulting a judge on the bench, 1412.

Wheat in≈øect, ccmmonly called the He≈ø≈øian fly from the notion of its being brought into this country by the He≈ø≈øians, was totally unknown in America till a few years after the commencement of the late war; it has ≈øince done much injury to the wheat in New York and the adjoining ≈øtates, but we are happy to under≈øtand that for the≈øe two or three la≈øt years, its ravages have been le≈øs de≈øtructive.
Wood's half-pence, which rai≈øed a great ferment in Ireland, were ≈øent thither, January 15, 1780.

Articles of religion, ≈øix for the e≈øtabli≈øhed church of England were publi≈øhed by Henry VIII. 1536; 42 publi≈øhed without con≈øent of parliament, 1552; the 42 reduced to 39, January, 1563; received the authority of parliament 1571; the 39 articles of the church of England were reduced by the bi≈øhops and clergy of the Prote≈øtant Epi≈øcopal church in America to the number of 20, 1789.

Bible hi≈øtory, cea≈øes, 340 B. C.; Septuagint ver≈øion, made 284; fir≈øt divided into chapters, 1253, the number of which is 929 in the Old Te≈øtament and 260 in the New. The fir≈øt Engli≈øh edition, was in 1536; the fir≈øt authori≈øed edition in England was in 1539; the ≈øecond tran≈ølation was ordered to be read in churches, 1549; the pre≈øent tran≈ølation, was fini≈øhed, September 1611; permitted by the Pope to be tran≈ølated into all the languages of the Catholic ≈øtates, February 28, 1759; the fir≈øt edition of the Bible printed in the United States, was by Robert Aitkin of Philadelphia, 178 ‚Ä¢ ; the Doway tran≈ølation of the Bible, printed by Matthew Carey, of Philadelphia, 1790; the Bible tran≈ølated into the Indian language by Rev. Mr. Elliot of New England, 1664.

Bi≈øhops, the fir≈øt in England, 694; fir≈øt in Denmark, 939; the form of con≈øecrating Engli≈øh bi≈øhops, was ordained, 1549; their order aboli≈øhed by parliament, October 9, 1646; re≈øtored, October 25, 1660; the number of the Engli≈øh bi≈øhops is, at pre≈øent, the two archbi≈øhops of Canterbury and York, and 24 bi≈øhops; tho≈øe of Ireland are 4 archbi≈øhops, and 18 bi≈øhops.

Bi≈øhops, the fir≈øt in America, was the Right Rev. Doctor Samuel Seabury, con≈øecrated bi≈øhop of Connecticut by four nonjuring prelates at Aberdeen in Scotland, November 14, 1784; the other American bi≈øhops are the Right Rev. William White, D. D. bi≈øhop of Penn≈øylvania, and the Right Rev. Doctor Samuel Provo≈øt bi≈øhop of New York, who were both con≈øecrated at London by the archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, February 4, 1787; and the Right Rev. Doctor Maddi≈øon, of Virginia, who was likewi≈øe con≈øecrated by the archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, 1790.

Burial placesIt has long been the opinion of many, that to bury the dead in the centre of populous cities, was highly injurious to the health of the living. This opinion appeared to be univer≈øally adopted by the citizens of Philadelphia ≈øoon after the mortality occa≈øioned by the Yellow Fever; but as danger ≈øeems now at a di≈øtance, no further attempt has been made to change the pre≈øent places of interment., fir≈øt permitted in cities in England, 742.

Cardinals, originally the pari≈øh prie≈øts of Rome; the title began to be u≈øed, 308; they did not elect the popes till 1160; wore the red hat (to remind them that they ought to ≈øhed their blood, if required, for religion) and were made princes of the church, 1222; the title of Eminence fir≈øt given them by Pope Urban VIII. about 1630.

Chri≈øtianity, propagated in Spain, 36; ≈øuppo≈øed to be fir≈øt introduced into Britain, 60; e≈øtabli≈øhed there by public authority, 181; introduced into Scotland, 212; propagated in Per≈øia, 408; began in France, 496; introduced into Frie≈øland, 698; into Germany, 719; embraced by the king of Denmark, for which he was dethroned, 825: preached in Sweden, about 850; e≈øtabli≈øhed in Ru≈ø≈øia, 985; in Hungary, in the tenth century; in Pru≈ø≈øia, in the eleventh; in Norway, in the twelfth; in part of Tartary, in the thirteenth; in Africa, at Guinea, &c. in the fifteeenth; and it made great progre≈øs in the Ea≈øt Indies, and in China, in the ≈øixteenth century; the American Indians, began to be in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtianity by the Rev. Mr. Elliot of New England, 1650.
