Go≈øpel, St. Mathew's written 44, St. Mark's in the ≈øame year, St. Luke's 55, and St. John's 97.
Go≈øpel, per≈øons ordered to ≈øtand, when it is read 399.
Gown and Ca≈ø≈øoc, began to be u≈øed in England, about 1670.
Grace, before and after meat, was a very ancient practice even in the heathen world.
Greek church, began 860.
HABIT, the clerical, began to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the lay habit, in the ≈øixth century.
Hair, the wearing of long, con≈øidered as a very ‚Ä¢ einous ≈øin, in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, March 1649, when the Governor and council entered into an a≈ø≈øociation again≈øt it.
Hallelujah, and Amen, in≈øtituted by Haggai the prophet 584 before Chri≈øt.
High and Low church, two di≈øtinct parties, occa≈øioned by the pro≈øecution of Sach ‚Ä¢ vral, for ≈øeditious ≈øermons began in England 1710.
Holy Gho≈øt, de≈øcent of the, May 24, 33.
Holy Water, fir≈øt u≈øed in churches 120.
Huguenots, prote≈øtants, fir≈øt ≈øo called in France 1560.
IDOLATRY, introduced by Ninus, king of A≈ø≈øyria, fir≈øt aboli≈øhed from Kent in England, 641.
Images, and reliques, reverence to, commenced 448, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed in England 1548, in Hungary and Germany 1785.

Impo≈øtors two, men, were crucified, for a≈ø≈øuming the character of Chri≈øt; and two women for pretending to be the Virgin Mary, and Mary Magdalene 1221. Jemima Wilkin≈øon of Rhode I≈øland pretended to be Chri≈øt, 1787.

Independents, or Congregationali≈øts, tho≈øe who hold that each congregation may govern them≈øelves in religious matters, had their fir≈øt meeting-hou≈øe in England 1616. In the New England States, there are more congregationali≈øts than tho≈øe of any other per≈øua≈øion.
Indulgences, invented in the eleventh century; fir≈øt di≈øpo≈øed of for money 1190.

Inqui≈øition, court of, began 1204; e≈øtabli≈øhed at Tholou≈øe 1229: in Spain 1482: aboli≈øhed in Naples 1782, in Tu≈øcany 1785. (In Spain where it ≈øtill continues, it now appears to be intended to an≈øwer the purpo≈øes of State, rather than tho≈øe of religion).
Invocation, of the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin and of the Saints, began to be practi≈øed 593.
JAMES's, St. Epi≈øtle of, written 59.
James St. the fe≈øtival of, in≈øtituted 1089.

January 30, ordered by the Briti≈øh Parliament, to be annually ob≈øerved as a day of fa≈øting and humiliation, to emplore ALMIGHTY GOD to avert from the Briti≈øh nation, the calamities which it de≈øerved for ≈øhedding the blood of their righteous ≈øovereign Charles I. who was
(as they ≈øay) martyred, on January 30, 1649: Even to the pre≈øent day, this ridiculous farce is ≈øtill kept up, and the anniver≈øary of the ju≈øt puni≈øhment of this infamous tyrant, is ob≈øerved with, at lea≈øt, as much ≈øolemnity, as Good Friday, the day appointed by ≈øeveral of the Chri≈øtian Churches, for commemorating the ≈øufferings of the Ble≈ø≈øed Je≈øus.
Jeremiah, wrote his lamentations, 610 before Chri≈øt.
Je≈øuits, ≈øociety of, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Ignatius Loyola, 1536, expelled England, 1604. Venice 1606. Portugal 1759. Naples 1768. The order aboli≈øhed by the Pope 1773: rev ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed in Ru≈ø≈øia 1783.

JESUS CHRIST, was born Monday, December 25, in the year of the world 4004, in that of Rome 725; his bapti≈øm by John, and his fir≈øt mini≈øtry 30: celebrated the la≈øt pa≈ø≈øover and in≈øtituted the ≈øacrament of the ≈øupper in its ≈øtead on Thur≈øday, April 2, was crucified, April 3, at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, aro≈øe April 5, and a≈øcended Thur≈øday, May 14, following, in the 33d year of his age.
Jews, 150,000, driven out of Spain 1492.
Joan, Pope, in 956. This was a fable to depict the effeminate manners of the times.
John, St. the apo≈øtle, wrote his epi≈øtle 92.
John, St. the Evangeli≈øt, wrote his revelation 96, and his go≈øpel 97.
Jo≈øhua, book of, written 415 before Chri≈øt.

Jubilee, at the end of every century, in≈øtituted by Pope Boniface VIII. 1300. The jubilee was afterwards celebrated every 50 years, by order of Clement VI. Succeeding Popes, afterwards reduced it to 25 years, at which period it is now fixed.
Jude, St. wrote his epi≈øtle 71.
KISSING, the Pope's foot, took its ri≈øe from kneeling to tho≈øe called ≈øovereigns, and began in the year 709.
Knee ordered, to be bent at the name of Je≈øus, 1275.
Koran, the Mahometan ≈øy≈øtem of faith, tran≈ølated into Latin, 1 ‚Ä¢ 43. (This book has been afterwards, tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh, and may now be ≈øeen in the Philadelphia Library).
LENT, the fa≈øt of, in≈øtituted 152.
Lights, fir≈øt u≈øed in Churches, in the day time 409.
Litanies, fir≈øt u≈øed in churches, 443: the fir≈øt in the Engli≈øh language 1343.
Liturgy, of the Church of England, fir≈øt read in Scotland, July 23, 1637.
Lollards, the ≈øect of, began 1315: pro≈øcribed by parliament 1406. Many of the Lollards were executed 1414.
Luke, St. wrote his go≈øpel, 55.
Lutherans, began 1517.
MAHOMETAN Sect, began 622.
Manichees ≈øect, began 343.
Mark, St. wrote his go≈øpel 44.

Marriage, the fir≈øt in≈øtitution of, by ceremony, is a≈øcribed to Cecrops king of Athens, 1556 B. C.: celebration of it in Churches, fir≈øt ordained about 1200. The fir≈øt celebrated in New England, was between Mr. Edward Win≈ølow, and Mrs. Su≈øannah White, May 12, 1621.
Mathew St. wrote his go≈øpel 44.
Ma≈øs, fir≈øt u≈øed in Latin 394: introduced into England 680.
Monk, the fir≈øt is ≈øaid to have been, Paul of Thebai ‚Ä¢ , about 250.

Moravians, or Unitas Fratrum, appeared in Bohemia 1457; in England 1737; fir≈øt introduced into America by Count Zinzindorf 1741. (No religious denomination has been more a≈ø≈øiduous, than the Moravians, in endeavouring to obtain converts for the Chri≈øtian religion, nor has any been more ≈øucce≈øsful).
Muggletonians, ≈øprung from L. Muggleton, a journeyman taylor, 1647.
NATIVITY, of the Virgin Mary, the fea≈øt of in≈øtituted, 695.
Nicene Creed, made 325, fir≈øt appointed to be read in Churches 336,
Nonjurors, or Jacobites, in Scotland, tho≈øe who were aver≈øe to the Hanoverian ≈øucce≈ø≈øion to the crown of Britain, began to pray for George III. and his family, May 25, 1788.
Nunneries, the fir≈øt founded in France, was near Poictiers 360. The fir≈øt in England erected 630.
Nunneries, aboli≈øhed by the French Convention 1793.
ORGANS, were more early than Job, ≈øee Gene≈øis iv. 21, and Job xxx. 31, fir≈øt u≈øed in Chri≈øtian Churches 751.
Orphan hou≈øe, in Georgia, founded by the Rev. Mr. George Whitfield 1740.
PASSOVER, in≈øtituted, Monday May 4, 1491: celebrated in the new temple, April 18, 515 B. C.

Paul, St. converted 33, caught up into the third heavens 44: wrote his fir≈øt epi≈øtle to the Corinthians, and that to the Galatians 51: fir≈øt epi≈øtle to the The≈ø≈øalonians 52; ≈øecond epi≈øtle to do. 53; ≈øecond epi≈øtle to the Corinthians and that to the Philippians, Ephe≈øians, Colo≈ø≈øians, and Philemon 62: to the Hebrews 63. Fir≈øt Epi≈øtle to Timothy, and that to Titus 65. Second Epi≈øtle to Timothy 66. St. Paul, died June 29, 67.
Pelagian ≈øect, began 382.
Penance, fir≈øt enjoined as a puni≈øhment 157.
Penitents, an order of Nuns, founded 1494.
Pentateuch, or the five book of Mo≈øes, written 1452 B. C.
Penteco≈øt, the fea≈øt of, e≈øtabli≈øhed 68.

Per≈øecutions, of the Jews.‚ÄîAntiochus, king of Syria, kills 40,000 Jews at Jeru≈øalem, and ≈øells 40,000 for ≈ølaves, 170 B. C.; the Romans de≈øtroyed 580,000, be≈øides tho≈øe who peri≈øhed by di≈øea≈øe and famine, A. D. 136; the Emperor Leo I. wanting to compel them to turn Chri≈øtians, they ≈øet fire to their hou≈øes at Con≈øtantinople and peri≈øhed in the flames, 722; many of them ma≈ø≈øacred in London, at the coronation of Richard I. 1189; they were all apprehended throughout England in one day; their effects confi≈øcated, and their per≈øons bani≈øhed the realm, to the number of 15,000, in 1287; they were ma≈ø≈øacred in Germany, on a ridiculous ≈øu≈øpicion of having poi≈øoned the ≈øprings and wells 1348.

Per≈øecutions, by the Jews, the fir≈øt 63; the ≈øecond 44. B. C. 200,000 Greeks and Romans were ma≈ø≈øacred by the Jews, headed by one Andreoe 115; the fir≈øt general per≈øecution of the Chri≈øtians was under Nero, 64; under Domitian 93; under Trajan 107; under Adrian 118; under Marcus Aurellius 164; under Severus 202; under Maximus 235; under Decius 250; under Valerian 257; under Aurelian 272; under Diocle≈øian 302; under Julian the Apo≈øtate 361.

Per≈øecutions, of the different ≈øects of Chri≈øtians again≈øt one another; a number of the followers of Luther, were killed in Germany by the Catholics, 1525, and in England 1556; Calvin had ≈øome per≈øons hanged who oppo≈øed his doctrines about 1560: ≈øeveral Catholics were executed for their religious principles, in the reign of Edward VI. of England, about 1550; Puritans were executed in the reign of Queen Elizabeth, about 1580; during the reign of Charles I. and II. of England, the Pre≈øbyterians were ≈øeverely per≈øecuted and many put to death; about this time a number of Pre≈øbyterians or Puritans, fled to New England, and in October 1656 pa≈ø≈øed a law, inflicting the puni≈øhment of death on ≈øuch Quakers, as ≈øhould return to that colony after bani≈øhment, and ≈øeveral ≈øuffered under this iniquitous law, which, however, was repealed 1661.
Thus each ≈øect or party, whil≈øt under the influence of bigotry and ≈øuper≈øtition, ≈øeemed to think they did God ≈øervice by per≈øecuting tho≈øe, who differed from them≈øelves in opinion.
Peter, St. wrote his fir≈øt epi≈øtle 60; His ≈øecond 66.
Pix or box, to hold the ho≈øt, ordered by the Lateran council 1215.

Pope, the title of formerly given to all bi≈øhops. The Emperor in 606, confined it to the bi≈øhops of Rome, and from this period the power of the Pope may be dated. The Pope's ≈øupremacy over the Chri≈øtian world, is ≈øaid by Prote≈øtant writers, to have been fir≈øt e≈øtabli≈øhed by, Bonniface III. 607; the cu≈øtom of ki≈ø≈øing the Pope's toes, was introduced 708; the Pope's temporal grandeur, commenced 755; Servius II. was the fir≈øt pope, who changed his name on his election 844; the fir≈øt pope, who kept an army was Leo IX. 1054; their a≈ø≈øumed authority was carried to ≈øuch exce≈ø≈øes, that they not only excommunicated, but even began to depo≈øe ≈øovereigns 1073; the Pope's authority fir≈øt introduced into England 1079; abrogated by parl ‚Ä¢ ament 1534; the word Pope, was ≈øtruck out of all Engli≈øh books 1541; ki≈ø≈øing the Pope's toe, and ≈øome other ceremonies equally ridiculous, and the order of the Je≈øuits aboli≈øhed by the late Pope Clement XIV. of famous memory 1773; The temporal power of the Pope has been for the≈øe many years rapidly declining, and indeed ≈øince the year 1787, it may be ≈øafely a≈ø≈øerted, that he has been de≈øtitute of all political influence in Europe; Burnt in effigy in Paris, May 4, 1791.

Praying, towards the ea≈øt, ordered by the Pope 532; Praying for the dead, is mentioned in the apochryphal book of the Macchabees; ≈øaid by Prote≈øtant writers, to be fir≈øt introduced into the Chri≈øtian Church, about 590.
Prede≈øtination, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Lucidus a prie≈øt of Gaul 470.

Prebyteriani≈øm, advanced by Calvin, who died 1564; made the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion of Scotland by John Knox,
about the time of Calvin's, death; the fir≈øt Pre≈øbyterian ≈øynod in America, was held at Cambridge, New England, 1637, when a form of church government was agreed on.
Pro≈øtration, at the elevation of the ho≈øt, ordained 1201.

Prote≈øtant, the name of, took its ri≈øe from the opponnents of the Church of Rome, having prote≈øted again≈øt the doctrines of that church at the diet of Spires in Germany 1529; the Prote≈øtant religion commenced in England, under Henry VIII. 1534.
Prote≈øtanti≈øm, tolerated in Germany 1624; in Bohemia 1707.
Purgatory, the doctrine of, according to Prote≈øtant writers, was invented 250; introduced into the Chri≈øtian church 511; made an article of faith 1545.

Puritans, prote≈øtants who fled from England to Germany, in the reign of Queen Mary, and returned in that of Queen Elizabeth, about 1560. (About 100 Puritans, who had fled from religious per≈øecution in England, arrived at a place in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, which in commemoration of the city in their native land, which they had la≈øt left, they denominated Plymouth, December 31, 1620. (This was the fir≈øt permanent ≈øettlement in New England).
Purple, given the cardinals by Paul II. 1465.

QUAKERS, the ≈øect of, founded by George Fox 1664; notwith≈øtanding their affirmation, was admitted by act of parliament as equivalent to an oath in 1696, the election of John Archdale, who was cho≈øen member of parliament was ≈øet a≈øide, becau≈øe he refu≈øed to take the oaths 1698; they began to be per≈øecuted in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts 1656, when a law was pa≈ø≈øed to bani≈øh them and inflicting the puni≈øhment of death, if they ≈øhould return.
Quieti≈øts, or Molini≈øts aro≈øe under Molinos, a prie≈øt of Sarago≈ø≈øa 1685.
RAMAZEIN, a fa≈øt ob≈øerved by the Mahometans, with the greate≈øt devotion, in≈øtituted about 630.
Religious hou≈øes, di≈ø≈øolved in England by Parliament 1537; in Germany by the Emperor Jo≈øeph 1782, and 1785; in France 1792.
Ring, appears to have been in u≈øe, among≈øt the Hebrews Gene≈øis xxxviii. 18. It was u≈øed by the ancient Gauls and Britons to di≈øtingui≈øh rank.
Ro≈øary, or beads fir≈øt u≈øed by Chri≈øtians, in their prayers 1093.
SABELLIANS, a ≈øect who, aro≈øe about 255.
Sacramentarians, appeared 1048.
Sanctuaries, in≈øtituted 617; totally aboli≈øhed in England 1541.
Saturnalia, fe≈øtivals in≈øtituted in Rome, in December 407 B. C.
Scribes, and Phari≈øees, commenced 31 B. C.

Septuagint, found in a ca≈øk 217.Charles Thomp≈øon, late ≈øecretary of Congre≈øs, has been for ≈øome time pa≈øt, employed in tran≈ølating this valuable book into the Engli≈øh language, which, it is expected, will be ≈øoon publi≈øhed.
Singing in churches, e≈øtabli≈øhed 67.
Socinians, aro≈øe under Socinus 1555.
Solomon, wrote his Eccle≈øia≈øtics, 981 B. C.
Spon≈øors, fir≈øt in≈øtituted 130
Standing, at reading of the Go≈øpel, introduced 406.
Surplices, fir≈øt u≈øed in churches 316.
Swedenburghers, the ≈øect, began 1760. (The doctrines of this religious ≈øociety, have been printed by Francis Bailey of Philadelphia).
TALMUD the, made, 117 B. C.

Temples, fir≈øt erected to the Gods by the Egyptians; They were all de≈øtroyed throughout the Roman empire, by Con≈øtantine the Great 331; Solomon's temple, which was founded, May 21, 1012, and completed, October 30, 1000 B. C. was the mo≈øt magnificent ≈øtructure ever erected.
Tenths, of church livings, fir≈øt collected in England 1226.
Tithes, fir≈øt given by Mo≈øes, to the tribe of Levi 1490, B. C. e≈øtabli≈øhed throughout England 844: by the Latteran council 1215.
Transfiguration, fe≈øtival of, fir≈øt ob≈øerved 700.
Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, introduced as an article of faith, about 840, oppo≈øed by the Engli≈øh church, 1000, received by it ≈øome time previous to 1066.
Trinitarians, the order of, in≈øtituted 1198.
Trinity, the word, fir≈øt applied to the per≈øons of the Godhead by Theophilus of Antioch, about 150.
Trinity Sunday, the fea≈øt of, in≈øtituted about 828: appointed to be held on the pre≈øent day 1334.
Trithei≈øts, the ≈øect of, aro≈øe 560.

Tutelar Saints, St. George of England and Portugal, St. Andrew of Scotland, St. Patrick of Ireland, St. David of Wales, St. Dennis, of France, St. James of Spain, St. Anthony, of Padua, St. Mark, of Venice, St. Colman of Au≈øtria, St. Tammany, of America.
UBIQUARIANS, the ≈øect of, began 1540.
Unction extreme, practi≈øed in the fir≈øt century. It became general 450.
Unitarians, the ≈øect of, revived 1553. Dr Prie≈øtley the celebrated advocate of that Doctrine, came to America 1794.

Univer≈øali≈øts, or tho≈øe who believe in the final ≈øalvation of all men, the celebrated Doctor Tillot≈øon, who
died 1694, appears from ≈øeveral of his Sermons, to have adopted that opinion. The univer≈øal churches in the United States, agreed on their articles of faith at Philadelphia, May 25, 1790, which were ≈øoon after publi≈øhed by Mr. Dob≈øon.
VESTMENTS, the wearing of, at the altar adopted 257.
Vi≈øitation, of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, the fe≈øtival of, in≈øtituted 1389.
Vulgate, edition of the bible, di≈øcovered 218: fir≈øt printed 1462.
WATER, mixed with wine, in the holy ≈øacrament, fir≈øt introduced 122.
Whit untide, fe≈øtival, in≈øtituted 813.

Witchcraft, ≈øix hundred condemned as wizards, and mo≈øt of them burnt in France 1609; twenty old women were burnt in Bretagne in France, for this ≈øuppo≈øed crime 1654; nine old women were burnt at Kali≈øh in Poland, charged with having bewitched, and rendered unfruitful the lands, belonging to a gentleman of the Palatinate 1775; ≈øeveral per≈øons, accu≈øed of witchcraft in Scotland, ≈øuffered death about 1600; di≈øturbances commenced, for this ≈øuppo≈øed crime in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts 1648: the frenzy at its height 1649; revived again and raged vehemently 1692; per≈øecutions for it began in Penn≈øylvania 1683.

div.head: Population, Government, Religion, &c. of the different continents, ≈øtates, empires, kingdoms, &c.

div.p: AFRICA, the continent of, contains 150,000,000 inhabitants; the government is de≈øpotic, and with re≈øpect to religion the greater number are Pagans: the others are Mahometans, and ≈øome few are Chri≈øtians. The number of ≈øquare miles, is 9,654,807.

America, contains 150,000,000 inhabitants, of whom the United States has at pre≈øent 4 milions; the other inhabitants are Indians, coloni≈øts from the different European powers, and negroes; the Indians are generally Pagans. In the United States there is free liberty of con≈øcience, for the peaceable profe≈ø≈øion of every religion. In South America, the Catholic is the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion; which a number of Indians have likewi≈øe embraced, and in North America, there are ≈øeveral Indian congregations both of Catholics and Prote≈øtants. America contains 14,110,874 ≈øquare miles, ≈øee United States.
A≈øia, the continent of, contains 500,000,000 inhabitants, and 10,768,823 ≈øquare miles, the government is highly de≈øpotic, and the religion, Pagani≈øm, Mahomatani≈øm, and a few Chri≈øtians.
Arabia, the inhabitants are Mahometans.
Au≈øtria, an archdukedom, its number of inhabitants is 4,182,000, and their religion Catholic.
BARBARY, the government of the different ≈øtates of, highly de≈øpotic, and the religion Mahometan.
Bavaria, a dukedom, contains 1,600,000 inhabitants, and the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Catholic.
Bohemia, a kingdom, contains 2,100,000 inhabitants, the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Catholic and Prote≈øtants, are tolerated.
Brandenburgh, a marqui≈øate, contains 1,007,232 inhabitants; their religion is the Lutheran, Calvini≈øt, and Catholic.
Britain, the European dominions of, contain about 13,500,000, ≈øee England and Scotland.
Brun≈øwick, a dukedom, contains 166,350 inhabitants, and Lutherani≈øm is the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion.
CANADA, a Briti≈øh province, contains 230,000 inhabitants; the greate≈øt number of whom are Catholics.

China, an Empire, contained in the year 1761, 198,214,553 inhabitants; the Chine≈øe, in religious matters, are in general the followers of Confucius, who≈øe doctrines, according to the Je≈øuits who re≈øided there, approximate to tho≈øe of Chri≈øtianity.
Cologn, an archbi≈øhopric, the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Catholic, and the number of inhabitants, about 550,000.
Connecticut, ≈øee United States.
DELAWARE, ≈øee United States.
Denmark, an ab≈øolute monarchy; the whole of the king of Denmark's ≈øubjects, in the year 1759, amounted to 2,444,000, and Lutherani≈øm is the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion.
ENGLAND, a limited monarchy, contains upwards of 7,000,000 of inhabitants; its e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the church of England, but all others are tolerated.

Europe, a continent, containing 2,749,349 ≈øquare miles, and 153,000,000 inhabitants, its government is different in different countries; Chri≈øtianity is the e≈øtabli≈øhed, religion, in every part of Europe except Turkey,
the Mahometan is e≈øtabli≈øhed, and in Lapland where the inhabitants are ≈øtill Pagans. According to Guthrie, the number of Prote≈øtants in Europe is only 24,000,000; whil≈øt the Catholics amount to 90,000,000.

FRANCE, was formerly a kingdom, but now a democratic republic, and contains 27,253,000 inhabitants. Previous to the late revolution the Catholic was the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion; but now the people enjoy an univer≈øal liberty of wor≈øhiping God according to the dictates of their own con≈øcience.
GENOA, a republic, Catholics.
Georgia, ≈øee United States.

Germany, an empire, contains 26,265,000 inhabitants; the Catholic religion prevails in the South of Germany; the Lutheran in the North, and the Calvini≈øt near the Rhine; the Jews and all other religions are tolerated throughout the Empire.
Greece, a part of Turkey, their religion is the Mahometan, Jewi≈øh, and a few Chri≈øtians.
HANOVER, an electorate, contains 750,000 inhabitants, who are Lutherans, Calvini≈øts, &c.
He≈ø≈øe Ca≈ø≈øel, a Landgraviate, contains about 900,000 inhabitants, who are with re≈øpect to religion Lutherans, Calvini≈øts, and Catholics.

Hungary, a kingdom, contains about 3,000,000 of inhabitants; their e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Catholic, although the major part of the inhabitants are Prote≈øtants or Greeks; all religions are now tolerated.

INDOSTAN, or India in general, contains about 110, 000,000 inhabitants, the greate≈øt number of whom are followers of Brumma; they believe in a ≈øupreme being,
whom they wor≈øhip with the greate≈øt reverence, as al≈øo in a future ≈øtate of rewards and puni≈øhments, and are of excellent morals; there are al≈øo, in Indo≈øtan, Mahometans and Chri≈øtians.
Ireland, a kingdom, contains 4,000,000 of inhabitants; the church of England is e≈øtabli≈øhed by law, although about 3,000,000 of the people are Catholics. All religions are tolerated.
Italy, under the pope, &c. contains 20,000,000 of inhabitants, and the Catholic is the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion.
KENTUCKY, ≈øee United States.
MARYLAND, and Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, ≈øee United States.
NEW-Jer≈øey, New-Hamp≈øhire, and New-York, ≈øee United States.
Naples, a kingdom, contains 4,500,000 inhabitants, who are Catholics.

Netherlands, or United Provinces, contain 2,000,000 inhabitants; previous to the late revolution, in Jan. 1795, this country though denominated a republic, was in fact an ari≈øtocracy; their e≈øtabli≈øhed religion was the Pre≈øbyterian, and all others tolerated. By the la≈øt accounts they appear to be now forming a con≈øtitution, agreeably to the genuine rights of man, and it can ≈øcarcely be doubted, that they will aboli≈øh that ≈øource of hypocri≈øy and irreligion, viz. a religious e≈øtabli≈øhment.
North Carolina, ≈øee United States.
Norway, a kingdom ≈øubject „Äà‚óä„Äâ Denmark; their religion Lutheran.

OSNABURGH, a bi≈øhopric, contains 120,000 inhabitants, who are LutheransAt the peace of We≈øtphalia, it was agreed that the Bi≈øhops ≈øhould be alternately of the Lutheran, and Catholic religion. Their pre≈øent ≈øpiritual guide is the Duke of York, the ≈øecond Son of George III. and Catholics.
PENNSYLVANIA, ≈øee United States.

Per≈øia, with re≈øpect to the population of this country, we have no certain account, although from the great armies it has rai≈øed, both in ancient and modern times, it mu≈øt be very great; the inhabitants are in general Mahometans; there are al≈øo a number of ≈øects, who have obviou≈øly Chri≈øtianity for the ground work of their religion.

Poland, with re≈øpect to government, has for a long time had a king although it might with propriety have been called an ari≈øtocracy; it contains 9,000,000 inhabitants, of whom 600,000 are Jews; the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Catholic, but all others are tolerated. What its government is to be in future, it is impo≈ø≈øible to conjecture, as their country has lately been over-run by that dete≈øtable enemy of the human ≈øpecies, the Empre≈øs of Ru≈ø≈øia, who ≈øeems at pre≈øent to have the power of regulating the affairs, of that unhappy country as ≈øhe plea≈øes"The race is not always to the ≈øwift, nor the battle to the ≈øtrong." The ≈øame God, who has enabled the American nation to effect their liberty, and the French to oppo≈øe ≈øo many enemies, will, we tru≈øt, ≈øupport them..
Portugal, a kingdom, contains 2,000,000 inhabitants, of whom 30,000 are Eccle≈øia≈øtics; the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Catholic.

Pru≈ø≈øia, a kingdom; the Pru≈ø≈øian dominions contained in the year 1779, 3,290,000 inhabitants; the e≈øtabli≈øhed
religion is the Lutheran and Calvini≈øt, and all others are tolerated.
RHODE I≈øland, ≈øee Unite States.
Ru≈ø≈øia, an empire, contains 20,000,000 inhabitants; their e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is the Greek; and all others are tolerated.
SARDINIA, the kingdom, of, contains 3,170,000 inhabitants; and their e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is Catholic.
Scotland, a kingdom, contains 2,000,000 inhabitants; their e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is Pre≈øbyterian; but all others are tolerated.
Sicily, the I≈øland of, contains 1,300,000 inhabitants, who are Catholics.
South Carolina, ≈øee United States.
Spain, a kingdom, contains 9,250,000 inhabitants, and the Catholic is the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion.
Sweden, a kingdom, contains 3,000,000 of inhabitants; the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion is Lutheran, but all others are tolerated.

Swi≈ø≈øerland, a republic, contains 2,000,000 inhabitants; it has 13 Cantons, ≈øix of whom are Prote≈øtants, and 7 Catholics; in both the Catholic and Prote≈øtant cantons, all religions are tolerated.

TARTARY, in A≈øia, concerning the number of its inhabitants, it is difficult to conjecture; with re≈øpect to re ‚Ä¢ igion there are ≈øome Idolators; but they in general believe in one ≈øupreme God, whom they con≈øider as a beneficent, omnipotent, and omni≈øcient being; there are al≈øo a number of Chri≈øtians.
Turkey, the ≈øubjects of the empire of, are e≈øtimated at 49,000,000; their religion is Mahometan, and their government highly de≈øpotic.

UNITED States, contain 4,000,000 inhabitants; the government is a republic, in which it may be ≈øafely a≈ø≈øerted, that the rights of man, are under the pre≈øent con≈øtitution as well, if not better ≈øecured than in any other country; with re≈øpect to religion, the United States have the honour, of having fir≈øt aboli≈øhed all religious e≈øtabli≈øhments; the example has been followed by France, and now in both countries, every man is left at liberty to wor≈øhip God according to the dictates of his own con≈øcience.

Penn≈øylvania, the Univer≈øity of, had its fir≈øt origin from an in≈øtitution called, "the College, Academy, and Charity Schools of the city of Philadelphia, in Penn≈øylvania," which commenced 1750, and was incorporated 1753. In the year 1779, the ≈øeminary was placed under new tru≈øtees, and its ≈øtyle changed to that of, "the Univer≈øity of the State of Penn≈øylvania." In the year 1789, in con≈øequence of an application being made to the legi≈ølature, by the former tru≈øtees, they were again rein≈øtated in their rights and property; hence two ≈øeminaries of general learning, began to exi≈øt in the ≈øame city, when confe≈ø≈øedly only one was wanting. In all 5 ≈øhips, 5 brigs, and 3 ≈øchoners, two of which ve≈ø≈øels were captured in 1785; ten do. 1793, and one in 1794 Of their crews, which con≈øi≈øted of 13 ma≈øters, 11 mates, 2 ≈øupercargoes, 4 ≈øecond mates, and 84 Seamen, 4 only have been redeemed. The remainder, according to accounts received, are reduced by the plague, hard labour, &c. to between 60 and 70; their ≈øufferings have been great; it, therefore gives us the mo≈øt ≈øincere plea≈øure to inform our readers, that mea≈øures have been at la≈øt adopted, by which, it is hoped, they will ≈øoon be re≈øtored to their friends and country.

Tirlemont, the battle of, began March 15, 1793, when after a conte≈øt of ≈øeveral days, the French, under Dumourier, were defeated.
Tobago, declared a neutral I≈øland 1748; ceded to the Briti≈øh 1763; taken by the French, June 2, 1781; retaken by the Engli≈øh 1793.

Toulon, ≈øurrendered to the Engli≈øh Admiral Lord Hood, who took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the town and ≈øhipping in the name of Louis XVII. Augu≈øt 29, 1793, when the tree of liberty, which had been erected there was converted into a gibbet for the republicans. The combined forces there, con≈øi≈øting of the Engli≈øh, Spaniards, Neopolitans, &c. made a vigorous ≈øally again≈øt the French, but were repul≈øed with the lo≈øs of 1200 men killed and wounded, and the Engli≈øh General O'Hara taken pri≈øoner, November 30, 1793; on December 19, following, the republicans attacked the town in a mo≈øt vigorous manner; when the combined forces, finding that all future re≈øi≈øtance was u≈øele≈øs, after having ≈øet fire to the ≈øhipping, ar≈øenals, &c. made a precipitate retreat.

Tournay, the battle of, between the French and Engli≈øh, when the former were defeated, May 10, 1794; again between the French and combined powers when the latter were defeated with great lo≈øs, May 17, and 18, following.

Tu≈øcan war, commenced 312 B. C.

Vincents, St. I≈øland of, taken by the Engli≈øh 1756, to whom it was ceded by the peace of 1763; taken by the French a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Chariabs, whom the Engli≈øh had treated with great inhumanity, June 17, 1779; re≈øtored to the Engli≈øh by the treaty of peace 1783; a war broke out between the Chariabs ≈øaid to be a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the French, and the Engli≈øh, March 1795; but we know not as yet how it is terminated.

div.head: Sea-fights, the mo≈øt Remarkable, ≈øince the Year 1300.
div.p: ‚Äî between the French and Engli≈øh, near Sluys' when 400 ≈øail, and 30,000 men belonging to the former were taken, 1340.

‚Äî between the Engli≈øh and the Spani≈øh Armada off Calais, when the latter were defeated, with the lo≈øs of 17 ≈øhips and 5000 men 1588.

‚Äî again near the coa≈øt of Flanders, when the Dutch lo≈øt 17 ≈øhips, June 2, 1653.
‚Äî off Port≈ømouth, when Admiral Blake took 11 Dutch men of war, and 30 merchant ve≈ø≈øels, February 10, 1653.
‚Äî again when the Dutch lo≈øt 30 ≈øhips, and their Admiral Van Tromp was killed, July 29, 1653.
‚Äî off Cadiz, between the Engli≈øh under Blake, and the Spaniards, when two galeons of an immen≈øe value were taken, September 1656.
‚Äî at the Canaries, where the Spaniards were again defeated by Blake, April 20, 1657.
‚Äî between the Engli≈øh under the Duke of York, and the Dutch, when the latter were defeated with the lo≈øs of 19 ≈øhips. The Engli≈øh lo≈øt only one, June 3, 1665.
‚Äî the Earl of Sandwich took 12 Dutch men of war, and two Ea≈øt India ve≈ø≈øels, September 4, 1665.
‚Äî between the Engli≈øh under the Duke of Albemarle, and the Dutch and French joined, which la≈øted 4 days, June 1666. The Engli≈øh lo≈øt nine, and the Dutch 15 ≈øhips.

‚Äî at the mouth of the Thames, between the Engli≈øh under Prince Rupert, and the Dutch under Ruyter, when the latter were defeated with the lo≈øs of 24 ≈øhips, 4 Admirals killed, and 4000 officers and ≈øeamen, July 25, and 26, 1665.
The Dutch fleet ≈øailed up the Medway almo≈øt as far as Chatham, and de≈øtroyed great part of the Engli≈øh fleet, June 11, 1667.
‚Äî at Solebay, when the Earl of Sandwich was blown up, and the Dutch defeated by the Duke of York, May 28, 1672.
‚Äî on the coa≈øt of Holland, between the combined fleets of France and Britain, and the Dutch, May 28, June 4, and Augu≈øt 11, 1673, in all of which the Dutch were defeated.
Sea fight, In the bay of Tripoli, when the Engli≈øh de≈øtroyed 4 ≈øhips of war, belonging to that ≈øtate, March 4, 1674.
‚Äî off Beachy-head, when ‚Ä¢ he Engli≈øh and Dutch were defeated by the French, June 30, 1690.
‚Äî off La Hogue, when the Engli≈øh under Admiral Rook, defeated the French with the lo≈øs of 19 ≈øhips, May 19, 1692.
‚Äî off St Vincent, when the Engli≈øh and Dutch were beaten by the French with great lo≈øs, June 16, 1693.
‚Äî near Vigo, when the Spaniards and French were defeated by the Engli≈øh and Dutch, under Sir George Rooke, with the lo≈øs of 20 ≈øhips, Augu≈øt 15, 1702.
‚Äî between the French and Engli≈øh, when the former were defeated Augu≈øt 24, 1704.
‚Äî off the Lizard, when the Engli≈øh were defeated, October 9, 1707.
Admiral Leake took 60 French ve≈ø≈øels laden with provi≈øions for their army, May 22, 1708.
Spani≈øh fleet de≈øtroyed by Sir George Byng, off Cape Pa≈ø≈øaro, in the Mediterranean, Aug. 11, 1718.
‚Äî off Toulon, between the combined fleets of France and Spain, and the Engli≈øh under Admiral Mathews, February 9, 1744.
‚Äî in the Ea≈øt Indies, when the French being defeated, retired to Pondicherry 1747.
‚Äî of Cape Fini≈øterre, when the French fleet were taken by Admiral An≈øon, May 3, 1747.
‚Äî of U≈øhant, when Admiral Hawke took ≈øeven French men of war, October 14, 1747.
The French defeated, by the Briti≈øh, under Admiral Bo≈øcaven, off Cape Lagos, Aug. 18, 1759.

‚Äî off Belli≈øle, between the Engli≈øh under Hawke and the French under Conflans, when the latter was beaten with the lo≈øs of one ≈øhip of the line taken, two ≈øunk and two burnt, November 20, 1759.
‚Äî on Lake Champlain, between the Briti≈øh and Americans, when the latter were defeated, October 11, 1776.
Sea-fight, off U≈øhant, between the Briti≈øh, under Keppel and the French, when both ≈øides claimed the victory, July 27, 1778.
‚Äî at Penob≈øcot, when the American fleet con≈øi≈øting of 18 armed ve≈ø≈øels, be≈øides tran≈øports, were almo≈øt entirely de≈øtroyed by the Briti≈øh, under Sir George Collier, July 30, 1779.
‚Äî between the Briti≈øh ≈øhip Serapis and the B ‚Ä¢ n Homme Richard, Captain Paul Jones, off Scarborough, September 23, 1779.

‚Äî off Cape St. Vincent, between 18 ≈øail of the Engli≈øh under Rodney, and 13 ≈øail of the Spani≈øh under Langara, when the former captured the Admiral, and 5 ≈øhips of the line: one was driven a≈øhore and one blown up, January 16, 1780.
‚Äî off Martinico, between the Engli≈øh, under Sir George Rodney, with 21 ≈øail, and the French, under Comte de Guichen, with 25 ≈øail, April 17, 1780.
‚Äî off ditto between do. May 15, and 19. The≈øe battles were indeci≈øive.
‚Äî at St. Jago, between the Engli≈øh, under Commodore John≈øon, and the French under Mon≈øieur Suffrein, when the latter were defeated, April 16, 1781.
‚Äî of Martinico, between the Engli≈øh under Sir Samuel Hood, and the French under De Gra≈ø≈øe, April 19, 1781.

‚Äî off the Dogger bank, between the Engli≈øh under Admiral Parker, and the Dutch under Zoutman, when great ≈ølaughter was committed on both ≈øides, Augu≈øt 5, 1781, a Dutch ≈øhip of 68 guns ≈øunk the day after the engagement.
‚Äî off Cape Henry, near Che≈øapeak bay, between the Engli≈øh under Admiral Graves, and the French under Du Barras, September 5, 1781.
‚Äî in the Ea≈øt Indies, between the Engli≈øh under Hughes, and the French under Suffrein, February 17, 1782.

Sea fight, off Martinico, between the Engli≈øh and French, when Admiral Rodney defeated the French then going to attack Jamaica, took five ≈øail of the line and their Admiral Count de Gra≈ø≈øe, April 12, 1782.
The ≈øame day, Admiral Hughes defeated the French under Suffrein, in the Ea≈øt Indies.
The ≈øame day, admiral Barrington captured 2 French ≈øail of the line and 19 tran≈øports, bound to the Ea≈øt Indies.
‚Äî again in the Ea≈øt Indies, between Admirals Hughes and Suffrein, when the Engli≈øh gained ≈øome advantage, July 6, 1782.
‚Äî again between the ≈øa ‚Ä¢ e commanders, of Trincomale, September 3, 1782.
‚Äî off Gibraltar, the Spaniards defeated in their grand attack on that garri≈øon, when their floating batteries were de≈øtroyed, September 13, 1782.
‚Äî off Gibraltar, a drawn battle, between the combined fleets of France and Spain, con≈øi≈øting of 46 ≈øail of the line, and the Briti≈øh of 34 under Lord Howe, October 20, 1782.

‚Äî in the gulph of Finland, between the Swedes, under the Duke of Sudermania, and the Ru≈ø≈øians under admiral Gregg, when the ≈ølaughter was great on both ≈øides, July 26, 1789, when each took one ≈øhip from the other, and the Ru≈ø≈øians had one ≈øunk.

‚Äî again, in Swenk≈øand, between the ≈øame powers, when the Swedes took or de≈øtroyed about 40 ve≈ø≈øels, con≈øi≈øting of galleys, xebecs, f ‚Ä¢ gates. &c. carrying in all 600 pieces of cannon, an took between 6 and ‚Ä¢ 000 pri≈øoners, Augu≈øt 1, 1790.
‚Äî off Sandy Hook, a de≈øperate engagement between the Amba≈øcade a French, and the Bo≈øton, a Briti≈øh f ‚Ä¢ igate, in which the latter was wor≈øted and their Captain killed, Augu≈øt 1, 1793.

‚Äî off U≈øhant, three bloody engagements were ≈øought, between the French and Briti≈øh fleets, when the former were ultimately defeated with the lo≈øs of „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øail of the line taken and one ≈øunk, May 30, and
31, and June 1, 1794. The Briti≈øh were, however, ≈øo much ≈øhattered, that they were under the nece≈ø≈øity of immediately returning to port; and thus the French were able to protect their fleet, returning from America with provi≈øions, which was the principal object of their crui≈øe.
Sea-fight, in the Mediterranean, between the French and Briti≈øh, when the former lo≈øt 2 ≈øail of the line, and the latter one, March 14, 1795.

div.head: States, Empires, Kingdoms, &c. Founded.

div.p: ALGIERS, was a Roman province 44 B. C.; ≈øeized by Barbaro≈ø≈øa 1516.
America, the only independent State in, is the United States, ≈øee United States.
Argos, the kingdom of, began 1586 B. C.
A≈ø≈øyria, the ancient kingdom of, began under Ninus 2084 B. C. and la≈øted about 1264 years.
Athens, the kingdom of, began 1556 B. C. and ended 1070 B. C.
Au≈øtria, ≈øee Germany.
BABYLON, the kingdom of, founded by Nimrod 2640 B. C.
Berne, united with the other Swi≈øs cantons, 1353.
Bohemia, the kingdom of, began 550.

Briti≈øh I≈ølands, they were originally inhabited by a people called Britons, of the ≈øame ≈øtock with the ancient Gauls or Celtae. England, South Britain, was invaded by Julius Cae≈øar 54 B. C.; ≈øubdued by Claudius 44 A. D. and completely ≈øo by Agricola 85; from which period till the year 428, the Romans kept po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; at that time the old inhabitants called in the Saxons to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them again≈øt the Pict ‚Ä¢ and Scots, who ≈øoon ≈øubdued the country to them≈øelves, and divided it into ≈øeven kingdoms called the Heptarchy. This government la≈øted till 829, when Egbert, having ≈øubdued and united the different kingdoms, under one government, was crowned king of England. The crowns of England and Scotland united, in the per≈øon of James Stuart, the ≈øixth of that name, king of Scotland, who ≈øucceeded to the throne of England, by the title of James I. 1603. The two kingdoms were united by
con≈øent of the parliaments of both nations, under the name of Great Britain 1707.

CHINA, the empire of, commenced under Fohi 2147, but its hi≈øtory does not extend above the ≈øixth century, B. C. This country was conquered by the Ea≈øtern Tartars, when the Emperor and family killed them≈øelves 1644. In this empire the Je≈øuits attempted to propagate Chri≈øtianity 1692, and were at fir≈øt very ≈øucce≈øsful; but upon their preaching up the ≈øupremacy of the Pope, the Emperor became alarmed and expelled all the mi≈ø≈øionaries, 1724.
Connecticut, ≈øee United States.
Corinth, the kingdom of, e≈øtabli≈øhed 1355 B. C.
DELAWARE, ≈øee United States.

Denmark, the fir≈øt account we have of its being a kingdom, is in 714; united under Margaret, with Sweden and Norway 1397; ≈øeparated from Sweden 1528. About the year 1448, the crown of Denmark fell to Chri≈øtian, Count of Oldenburgh, by who≈øe de≈øcendants the United kingdoms of Denmark and Norway are ≈øtill governed.

EAST Indies, were fir≈øt di≈øcovered by the Romans, but authors di≈øagree with re≈øpect to the time. This far however, we know, with certainty, that Alexander the Great made exten≈øive conque≈øts in this country, 327 B. C. The fir≈øt commercial intercour≈øe of the Engli≈øh with the Ea≈øt Indies, was a private adventure of three ≈øhips fitted out from England 1591; of which number only one arrived at that country. The Captain on his return gave ≈øuch information to his employers, as to occa≈øion a capital mercantile voyage. The e≈øtabli≈øhment of the fir≈øt Briti≈øh Ea≈øt India company 1600; which ≈øince that period has carried on an exten≈øive commerce,
and by force and fraud made them≈øelves ma≈øters of great part of that heretofore, happy country.
England, ≈øee Briti≈øh I≈øles.

FRANCE, the country of the ancient Gauls, a colony of the Belgae from Germany were permitted to ≈øettle in it, 200 B. C. It was conquered by the Romans 25 B. C.; over-run by the Goths, Vandals, &c. who divided it among≈øt them≈øelves from A. D. 400, to 476; when the Franks, another ≈øet of German emigrants, compleated the foundation of the late kingdom of that country, under Pharamond. It was peopled by the natives of Germany, who cro≈ø≈øed the Rhine to invade the Gauls. The a≈ø≈øemblies called the States General, fir≈øt met 1302, and continued till 1614. This country had long been ≈øubject to the mo≈øt de≈øpotic government, and their national debt had become ≈øo enormous, that it was impo≈ø≈øible to pay the intere≈øt. The clamours of the public creditors and of the people at large, arre≈øted the attention of the court, and to appea≈øe them, a meeting of repre≈øentatives of the Clergy, Nobility, and people was called, who convened at Paris, May 5, 1789. The Tiers etats or repre≈øentatives of the people, after u≈øing various effects to obtain an union with the clergy and nobility, without ≈øucce≈øs, declared them≈øelves the National A≈ø≈øembly, and proceeded to bu≈øine≈øs, June 17, following; and on the 19th they were joined by a majority of the Clergy. On the 20th the repre≈øentatives of the people, were repul≈øed from the door of their u≈øual place of meeting, by an armed force ≈øent thither, by order of the court. Determined to per≈øevere in the regeneration of France, they then a≈ø≈øembled in a Tennis court, where, in the mid≈øt of applauding thou≈øands, they took a ≈øolemn oath "never to ≈øeparate, till the con≈øtitution ≈øhould be completed," on the 23d the king held, a royal ≈øe≈ø≈øion, when he declared null the deliberations and re≈øolves of the 17th, and ordered the deputies immediately to ≈øeparate and to appear before him next day.
When the king retired, he was followed by the nobility and a part of the clergy; but the deputies of the commons remained on the benches, and declared "that they were there by the voice of the people, and that nothing ≈øhould expel them but the power of the bayonet." The Ba≈øtille was taken by the national guards, and the governor and a number of other officers killed by the populace, on account of their perfidy, July 14. In November the A≈ø≈øembly aboli≈øhed the u≈øe of Lettres de Catchet, and the di≈øtinction of orders; on the 4th Feb. 1790, the king voluntarily appeared before the National A≈ø≈øembly, and declared, "that he would defend the new con≈øtitution to the la≈øt moment of his exi≈øtence;" and on June 20, 1791, as a proof of his ≈øincerity, departed privately with his family, from Paris, with a view, as was univer≈øally believed, of levying war again≈øt his country, and left a paper behind him, revoking all his prote≈øtations of attachment to the new con≈øtitution. He was, however, intercepted at Varennes and reconducted back to Paris, June 25; on July 17, a great concour≈øe of people a≈ø≈øembled in the Champ de Mars, with the profe≈ø≈øed de≈øign of petitioning, again≈øt the re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the king. The≈øe were however di≈øper≈øed by the National guard under La Fayette, but not before 12 men were killed, and 50 or 60 wounded; on September 13, the king appeared in the A≈ø≈øembly and ≈øolemnly ≈øwore, "to be faithful to the nation and to the law, and to employ the powers ve≈øted in him for the maintenance of the con≈øtitution, and the due execution of the law." The A≈ø≈øembly ≈øoon after pa≈ø≈øed a decree authori≈øing the bani≈øhment of nonjuring prie≈øts, and another for the e≈øtabli≈øhment of a camp in the neighbourhood of Paris, to both of which the king gave his con≈øtitutional veto. From this unpopular mea≈øure, his flight, &c. his attachment to the new order of things was much que≈øtioned; hence petitions were pre≈øented to the a≈ø≈øembly for his depo≈øition on 3d, 6th, and 7th of Augu≈øt 1792, in con≈øequence of which, and of the ma≈ø≈øacre at the Thuillieries on the 10th following, of
which he was accu≈øed as being the author, he was ≈øu≈øpended from his office and committed to the Temple; the a≈ø≈øembly al≈øo decreed the calling of a convention, which met on September 20, and pronounced "the eternal abolition of royalty in France. On December 11, the king was brought to trial. He was afterwards condemned and beheaded, on January 21, 1793; on June 23, following, the convention agreed upon a con≈øtitution purely democratic, which, however, amid≈øt the din of arms, and the jarring of contending parties, it has been hitherto found impracticable to put in execution. During the war, the articles of confederation had ≈øerved to keep the States united; but upon the return of peace, the general government was found, by no means to po≈ø≈øe≈øs tho≈øe powers, which are nece≈ø≈øary for the right admini≈øtration of a well regulated republic. In 1785, Mr James Madi≈øon, at pre≈øent a repre≈øentative in Congre≈øs, brought forward a motion in the hou≈øe of Delegates of Virginia, to appoint commi≈ø≈øioners, who, in concurrence with others, to be appointed by the different States, ≈øhould form a ≈øy≈øtem of commercial regulations, to be recommended for adoption to the different State legi≈ølatures. In con≈øequence of this recommendation, commi≈ø≈øioners from ≈øeveral of the States met at Annapolis in 1786; but finding that the States were generally not repre≈øented, and that the authority, given by ≈øuch as were, fell far ≈øhort of the objects to be accompli≈øhed, they agreed to reque≈øt of Congre≈øs, to recommend to the different States, to ≈øend deputies to a general convention, to be held at Philadelphia, in the following year, for the purpo≈øe of devi≈øing ≈øuch a form of government, as would be≈øt promote the welfare and happine≈øs of their con≈øtituents. In
May 1787, the Federal convention a≈ø≈øembled, and on September 17, recommended to the different States the new con≈øtitution, or pre≈øent ≈øy≈øtem of federal government. This con≈øtitution underwent the mo≈øt ≈øevere examination, and after a full di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, in the different State conventions, was at la≈øt adopted by all. The new government was organized at New York, March 3, 1789, and George Wa≈øhington was the fir≈øt Pre≈øident, John Adams the fir≈øt Vice Pre≈øident, and Frederic Augu≈øtus Muhlenburg the fir≈øt ≈øpeaker of the hou≈øe of repre≈øentatives. Under this excellent and hitherto wi≈øely admini≈øtered con≈øtitution, the citizens of the United States have experienced a degree of commercial and agricultural pro≈øperity, unknown to other nations, and while the different governments of Europe, are at pre≈øent convul≈øed to the very foundation, by the firm and temperate conduct of our Executive, we have ≈øtill enjoyed, that greate≈øt of all ble≈ø≈øings, peace. One circum≈øtance alone has tended to interrupt our tranquillity, viz, the in≈øurrection which broke out in the counties of Allegany, Wa≈øhington, Fayette, and We≈øtmoreland in Penn≈øylvania, on account of the exci≈øe, in 1794, This, however, was happily ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by the prudence of the Pre≈øident of the United States, and the good conduct of the militia, who, at his call, readily ≈øtepped forth in ≈øupport of the violated laws of their country, and order was re≈øtored without blood≈øhed. Having given this cur≈øory view of the foundation of the general government, we now proceed to the individual States, taking them according to their geographical order, from North to South.
VERMONT, State of, declared independent by its convention at Wind≈øor, December 25, 1777; admitted into the federal union, March 4, 1791.

New Hamp≈øhire, grant of, by the Plymouth company 1621; and fir≈øt began to be ≈øettled 1623. It was put under the juri≈ødiction of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts 1650, and
≈øeparated from that government 1679. In 1692, the inhabitants again petitioned to be united with Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, and were for a ≈øhort time under their juri≈ødiction. A provincial Congre≈øs took up the civil government, January 5, 1776, and on October 31, 1783, they e≈øtabli≈øhed their pre≈øent con≈øtitution.

Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, grant of, by the Plymouth company, to Sir Henry Ro≈øwell and others 1627; a royal charter granted 1628. Emigration to this country was prohibited by England 1633. The fir≈øt general court held by repre≈øentation was 1634. The Governor and a≈ø≈øi≈øtants fir≈øt ≈øat in a ≈øeparate apartment from the Repre≈øentatives 1644. In con≈øequence of a proclamation i≈ø≈øued by General Gage, the repre≈øentatives met at Salem, and re≈øolved them≈øelves into a provincial Congre≈øs, October 5, 1774. A convention met for ≈øettling a con≈øtituion, September 1, 1779, and continued by adjournment until March 2, 1780, when they agreed on a con≈øtitution which was afterwards ratified by the general court, in June following. An in≈øurrection headed by Shays, Par≈øons, &c. broke out in this State in 1786, but was ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed without much difficulty. The ringleaders were convicted, but afterwards pardoned by government.

Rhode I≈øland, ≈øettlement of, fir≈øt began by Mr. Roger Williams, and his per≈øecuted brethren 1635. Their fir≈øt charter was granted 1662, which was vacated 1684, and again re≈øumed 1689. Through the whole of the late war, this Statemanife≈øted the mo≈øt patriotic ≈øpirit. Since the peace they have uniformly evinced an exce≈ø≈øive jealou≈øy for their rights, and, therefore, when it was propo≈øed to inve≈øt Congre≈øs, with power to levy an impo≈øt of five percent on imports, by its pertinacious re≈øi≈øtance, was the principal means of defeating the mea≈øure. It al≈øo remained long ob≈øtinate again≈øt the adoption of the Federal con≈øtitution. Its ob≈øtinacy, however, was at la≈øt overcome, and on May 29, 1790, it became a member of the Federal union.

Connecticut, the fir≈øt grant of, made by the Pre≈øident and Council of Plymouth to the Earl of Warwick 1630. The fir≈øt charter was granted by Charles II. 1662. The con≈øtitution of this State is founded on their charter, and as the people have been contented with that form of government, they have not framed a new con≈øtitution, ≈øince the declaration of Independence.

New York, ≈øtate of, was fir≈øt ≈øettled by the Dutch 1614, who ≈øurrendered to the Engli≈øh, under Colonel Nichols, Augu≈øt 27, 1664, to whom it was confirmed by the peace of Breda 1667. The fir≈øt a≈ø≈øembly of repre≈øentatives of the people was held 1683. On April 20, 1777, New York e≈øtabli≈øhed an independent con≈øtitution.

New Jer≈øey, originally a Dutch ≈øettlement, had its fir≈øt charter granted to James Duke of York 1634, who afterwards granted it to Lord Berkeley, and Sir George Carteret 1644. The proprietors ≈øurrendered their rights to the crown 1702, and it continued a royal Government, until July 2, 1776, when the inhabitants e≈øtabli≈øhed an independent con≈øtitution.

Penn≈øylvania, charter of, granted to William Penn, March 4, 1680. The fir≈øt General A≈ø≈øembly met at Che≈øter, December 4, 1682. At this time William Penn effected an union of the lower counties, now the State of Delaware, with Penn≈øylvania Mr. Penn granted a new charter, which was merely a con≈øtitution or form of government; but as it was found inconvenient, it was given up in May 1700, and a new one granted, October 28, 1701. The inhabitants, of the lower counties, refu≈øed to accept this charter, and thus ≈øeparated them≈øelves from the province of Penn≈øylvania. They afterwards had their own a≈ø≈øembly, in which the Governor of Penn≈øylvania pre≈øided. This State adopted an independent con≈øtitution 1776; and e≈øtabli≈øhed the pre≈øent 1790.

Delaware, the State of, originally ≈øettled by the Swedes and Fins. The people of this ≈øtate, in September 1776, by their repre≈øentatives, cho≈øen for the expre≈øs
purpo≈øe, a≈ø≈øembled and e≈øtabli≈øhed a form of government, which in 1792, was ≈øuperceded by their pre≈øent con≈øtitution, ≈øee Penn≈øylvania.

Maryland, charter of, granted to Lord Baltimore, June 20, 1632. The fir≈øt regular a≈ø≈øembly, was con≈øtituted by a law pa≈ø≈øed 1638; and in the year 1642, was divided into two hou≈øes, In the year 1689, a rumour was artfully di≈ø≈øeminated, "that a Popi≈øh admini≈øtration, ≈øupported by Papi≈øts had leagued with Indians, to cut off the Prote≈øtants in the province; nor was it po≈ø≈øible for government to ≈øatisfy the people of the fal≈øehood, folly and ab≈øurdity of the report. The Proprietary, therefore found him≈øelf con≈øtrained to ≈øurrender tho≈øe prerogatives, which he had uniformly exerci≈øed, with an unexampled attention to the rights of the people. In the year 1716, the government was re≈øtored to the Proprietor, and continued in his and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors hands till the late revolution. The convention of this State, re≈øolved on mea≈øures for ≈øecuring the province and providing for its defence, July 26, 1775, and on Augu≈øt 14, 1776, agreed on their independent con≈øtitution.

Virginia,Virginia, according to its ancient limits, comprehended the greate≈øt part of the new United States, as it extended from the 34th to the 45th degree of latitude. fir≈øt began to be ≈øettled 1584. King James I. of England, granted letters patent to Sir Thomas Gage and his a≈ø≈øociates, for the ≈øettlement of this country, April 10, 1606, and a ≈øecond, on a more exten≈øive ≈øcale 1609. In 1621, two councils were appointed, the one to be called the council of State, and the other the General A≈ø≈øembly. In 1624, king James ≈øu≈øpended their charter, and in 1626, the government wholly reverted to the crown. In 1642, the Virginians appear to have been unea≈øy with Cromwell's government, to which however, they ≈øubmitted in 1651, after having fir≈øt ≈øecured their rights, by ≈øtipulation. Their
convention agreed on an independent con≈øtitution, July 5, 1776.

North Carolina, the inhabitants of, were but few, till the year 1700, when their number was augmented by the arrival of a body of Palatines from Germany, who had been reduced to the greate≈øt indigence, by the calamities of war. Previous to the year 1728, North and South Carolina had con≈øtituted one government; they were then, however, divided, for the more commodious admini≈øtration of affairs. In 1775, North Carolina, united with the other colonies again≈øt Briti≈øh oppre≈ø≈øion, and on December 16, 1776, e≈øtabli≈øhed their independent con≈øtitution.

South Carolina, including North Carolina and Georgia, the charter of, granted 1662. Their fir≈øt legi≈ølative a≈ø≈øembly convened 1669. They were at fir≈øt governed by a ≈øy≈øtem framed by Mr. John Locke; but having found by experience, that this ≈øy≈øtem was inapplicable to their ≈øituation, it was aboli≈øhed in 1692. They agreed on an independent form of government in 1776, which was e≈øtabli≈øhed by act of the legi≈ølature, May 19, 1778. On May 11, 1779, the civil authority propo≈øed to general Prevo≈øt, that the ≈øtate ≈øhould remain neuter, till the clo≈øe of the war, and that they would then follow the fate of their neighbours, provided, that the Briti≈øh army ≈øhould be withdrawn. But as this propo≈øal was not excepted, a general revolt took place in favour of Congre≈øs, July 1780.

Georgia, the ≈øtate of, obtained their charter 1732; acceded to the articles of confederation, July 1775; and on May 6, 1789, they ratified their pre≈øent con≈øtitution, which is formed upon a plan ≈øimilar to that of the United States.
Territory, N. W. of the Ohio, an ordinance of Congre≈øs was pa≈ø≈øed for its temporary government, July 13, 1787.

Kentucky, the State of, has, perhaps, been one of the mo≈øt growing colonies in the world, as it only began to be ≈øettled in the year 1754; and in 1790, according
to the cen≈øus contained 73,670 ≈øouls; but from the imperfect manner in which that enumeration was made, the rapid encrea≈øe of population, and the continual migrations from the ‚Ä¢ ther States, it is certain that at pre≈øent, May 1795, the number mu≈øt be more than double. This territory was erected into an independent State, by act of Congre≈øs, December 6, 1790, and received into the union, June 1, 1792.
Territory, South of the Ohio, an ordinance of Congre≈øs, for its temporary government was pa≈ø≈øed by Congre≈øs 1787.

Wales, fir≈øt inhabited by Britons, on their being expelled from England by the Saxons 685; conquered by William I. 1091. The whole country was ≈øubdued by Edward I. 1282. The Welch, however were not entirely reconciled to this revolution, till the Queen happened to be brought to bed of a ≈øon at Carnarvon, in 1284, whom Edward ≈øtiled Prince of Wales, which title, the heir apparent to the crown of Britain, has borne ever ≈øince. Wales was incorporated with England by act of parliament 1535.

EAST India Company, the Briti≈øhHappy, thrice happy, would it have been for India, if it had never been vi≈øited by the≈øe commercial tyrants. To relate the many in≈øtances of rapine, de≈øolation, and inju≈øtice which a lu≈øt of gain has induced them to commit, would require many volumes. Let the following extracts ≈øuffice. Lord Cornwallis, in a letter dated 18th September, 1789, has the following remarkable words: "I can ≈øafely affirm, that one third of the Company's territory in Indo≈øtan, is now a jungle inhabited by wild bea≈øts;" and Colonel Dow, a Scotch officer, who had been long in India, and who wrote the hi≈øtory of Indo≈øtan, thus de≈øcribes the effect of their barbarity in that unhappy country. "The civil wars, to which our violent de≈øire of creating nabobs give ri≈øe, were attended with tragical events. Bengal was depopulated by every ≈øpecies of public di≈øtre≈øs. In the ≈øpace of ≈øix years, half the great cities of this opulent kingdom were rendered de≈øolate; the mo≈øt fertile fields in the world laid wa≈øte, and five millions of harmle≈øs and indu≈øtrious people were either expelled or de≈øtroyed. Want of fore≈øight became more fatal than innate barbari≈øm; and men found them≈øelves wading through blood and ruin, when their only object was ≈øpoil." e≈øtabli≈øhed 1600.

ManufacturesEvery friend to America mu≈øt rejoice at the rapid progre≈øs of its manufactures, and tho≈øe gentlemen of affluence who employ their capital in promoting them, may be ≈øaid with propriety to de≈øerve well of their country. Among≈øt this number, there is none more con≈øpicuous than John Nichol≈øon, E≈øq late Comptroller General of the ≈øtate of Penn≈øylvania, who is at pre≈øent concerned, as principal, in the following manufactures, now either in operation, or contracted for, and in preparation, in and near the city of Philadelphia; 1≈øt. a factory for making the machinery and apparatus nece≈ø≈øary for carding and ≈øpinning cotton; 2d. a ditto for wool; 3d. two mills for carrying on the carding and ≈øpinning of cotton, one of 2500 ≈øpindles, and the other of 500; 4th. a cotton ≈øtocking factory, to con≈øi≈øt of forty looms; 5th. another ditto of a le≈øs number to be increa≈øed as it progre≈ø≈øes; 6th. a factory of weavers, to con≈øi≈øt of 40 looms or more; 7th. a factory for making the machinery for carding and ≈øpinning wool; 8th. a manufactory for making the machinery for cotton printing and bleeching; 9th. a cotton printing and bleaching factory; 10th. a factory for making cloths, without ≈øpinning or weaving; 11th. a hat manufactory on an improved plan; 12th. a button manufactory; 13th. a manufactory for clearing buttons; 14th. a manufactory for making planes and all ≈øuch kinds of edge tools; 15th. a gla≈øs manufactory; 16th. a manufactory for making oil cloths, floor cloths, &c. 17th. a newly invented manufactory for weaving ≈øtraps for carriages, hollow ho≈øe, for fire engines, ≈øhips, &c. 18th. a foundery for ca≈øting; 19th. a manufactory for con≈øtructing Rum≈øey's improvements on mills; 20th a manufactory to make ≈øteam engines applicable to mills, breweries, watering cities, &c. with various others on a le≈øs ≈øcale., the Penn≈øylvania ≈øociety for encouraging, in≈øtituted 1787.

Slavery
The zeal and activity of this ≈øociety has been crowned with uncommon ≈øucce≈øs, and has given ri≈øe to a number of ≈øimilar in≈øtitutions, not only in the United States, but al≈øo in Europe. A convention of delegates from the different ≈øocieties in the United States, met at Philadelphia, January 1, 1794, when they elected Jo≈øeph Bloomfield, New Jer≈øey, as their pre≈øident. In con≈øequence of a memorial which they pre≈øented to Congre≈øs, the citizens and re≈øidents of the United States were, by a law, pa≈ø≈øed March 22, 1794, prohibited from "procuring, from any foreign kingdom, place or country, the inhabitants of ≈øuch kingdom, place or country, to be tran≈øported to any foreign country, port or place whatever, to be ≈øold or di≈øpo≈øed of as ≈ølaves." In January 1795, delegates from the ≈øeveral ≈øocieties again met in convention at Philadelphia, when they elected Benjamin Ru≈øh, M. D. as pre≈øident, and Walter Franklin, E≈øq of Philadelphia, ≈øecretary.
The members elected by the different ≈øocieties to compo≈øe this convention, were as follows:
From the Connecticut Society, Jonathan Edwards, Uriah Tracy, Zephaniah Swift.
‚Äî Providence Society, (Rhode-I≈øland,) Theodore Fo≈øter, George Ben≈øon.
