‚Äî New-Jer≈øey, Jo≈øeph Bloomfield, William Coxe, jun. James Sloan, John Wi≈øtar and Franklin Davenport.
‚Äî Penn≈øylvania Society, William Rawle, Robert Patter≈øon, Benjamin Ru≈øh, Samuel Coates, Ca≈øpar Wi≈øtar, James Todd, Benjamin Say.
‚Äî Wa≈øhington Society, in Penn≈øylvania, Thomas Scot, Ab≈øalom Beard, Samuel Clark.
‚Äî Delaware Society, Richard Ba≈ø≈øet, John Ral≈øton, Allen M'Lane, Caleb Boyer.
‚Äî Wilmington Society, ≈øtate of Delaware, Cyrus Newlin, James A. Byard, Jo≈øeph Warner, William Poole:
‚Äî Maryland Society, Samuel Sterret, Adam Fonerdon, Jo≈øeph Town≈øend, Jo≈øeph Thornburgh, George Buchanan, John Bank≈øon, Philip Moore.
Che≈øtertown Society, (Maryland), Edward Scott, James Hou≈øton.
There is al≈øo a ≈øociety at Choptank, Maryland, and another at Richmond, Virginia. The convention are again to meet on the 1≈øt of January 1796. We may add, that the Penn≈øylvania Society has the glory of having originated this ≈øy≈øtem of oppo≈øition to the traffic and commerce of our fellow creatures; and that from a very exten≈øive and regular corre≈øpondence kept up between it, and tho≈øe founded on ≈øimilar principles, in the different parts of the world, there is every rea≈øon to believe that their efforts will be finally crowned with complete ≈øucce≈øs. The French convention has already declared liberty to all men without exception. Long debates have taken place in the Briti≈øh parliament on the ≈øame ≈øubject, and it is likely, that, by that government, the trade will be ≈øpeedily aboli≈øhed. In ≈øeveral of the American ≈øtates there are few, and in others no ≈ølaves. That there ≈øhould be any under a government of equal liberty, and which declares that all men are born alike free, mu≈øt to the thinking part of mankind, excite a≈øtoni≈øhment: but the pre≈øent citizens of the United States are too enlightened, for a much longer time, to tolerate ≈øuch an enormity, which experience has confirmed to be ≈øubver≈øive of ju≈øtice and morality, incompatible with ≈øound policy, repugnant to the principles of a republican government, and contradictory to the benevolent ≈øpirit of the Chri≈øtian religion. , the Society for promoting the abolition of, the fir≈øt was formed in Penn≈øylvania in 1774.
South Sea Company, London, incorporated 1556.
Stockholm, the Royal Academy of Sciences, in≈øtituted 1750.
Su≈øquehannah, the Company for building a Bridge over it, in≈øtituted April 11th, 1793.
TURKEY Company incorporated by Britain, 1579.
VINES. Company for promoting their cultivation, in≈øtituted March 22, 1793.
WESTERN Inland Navigation Company of New York, incorporated 1792.

div.head: Earthquakes, Famines, Inundations, Storms, Tempe≈øts, Fro≈øts, Accidental Fires, &c.

div.p: ALEXANDRIA library, which contained 400,000 manu≈øcripts, de≈øtroyed by fire 47 years B. C.
Am≈øterdam opera-hou≈øe burnt, when 150 per≈øons lo≈øt their lives 1772. The admiralty hou≈øe and its valuable ≈øtores were de≈øtroyed by fire, July 6, 1791.
Archangel, Ru≈ø≈øia, damaged by a dreadful fire, Oct. 16, 1777.
Ard≈øchin≈øchan, in Turkey, de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, when 12,000 inhabitants were buried in the ruins, 1784.
Arequipo, in South America, almo≈øt ruined by an earthquake, 1584.
Avelino, a city in Naples, de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, Nov. 29, 1732.
BALBEC, Turkey, totally obliterated by an earthquake, Dec. 5, 1759.

Barbadoes, the i≈øland of, much damaged by fire in May and December 1766: much damaged by a dreadful hurricane, which de≈øtroyed many hou≈øes, and left none on the i≈øland undamaged, Oct. 10, 1780. A peregrination of the earth de≈øtroyed ≈øeveral habitations, mills, &c. &c. October 16, 1784: much damaged by a ≈øtorm, Sept. 2, 1786: much injured by a hurricane, Oct. 23, 1793.

Berghen, in Norway, had 1600 families burnt out of their dwellings, 1756; con≈øiderably damaged by fire, January 1795, when the flames were at la≈øt extingui≈øhed by the intrepidity of the crews of ≈øome French frigates lying in that harbour, to whom, on the 22d January, the magi≈øtrates and citizens returned their public thanks.

Bo≈øton, Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, ≈øu≈øtained a great lo≈øs by fire, in which 45 dwelling hou≈øes, one meeting hou≈øe, and ≈øeveral ≈øtores were con≈øumed, 1676; again Aug. 8, 1679, when 80 dwelling hou≈øes, 70 warehou≈øes, and ≈øeveral ve≈ø≈øels were con≈øumed; ≈øu≈øtained ≈øome injury by an earthquake, Oct. 29, 1727; ≈øu≈øtained a lo≈øs by fire, of its court-hou≈øe and records, Dec. 23, 1747; damaged by fire to the amount of 444,000 dollars, March 20, 1760; again in 1761, 1764, and in 1775; upwards of 100 hou≈øes burnt, April 20, 1787; much damage ≈øu≈øtained by fire, Dec. 1794.
Brazil ≈øu≈øtained ≈øome damage by an earthquake 1772.

Bre≈øt magazine de≈øtroyed by fire, to the value of at lea≈øt 30,000,000 dollars, Jan. 19, 1744; the marine ho≈øpital burnt with 50 galley ≈ølaves, Dec. 1, 1766; the magazine de≈øtroyed by fire, to the value of between four and five millions of dollars, July 10, 1784.
Bridgetown, Barbadoes, de≈øtroyed by fire, April 18, 1668; had 160 dwelling hou≈øes de≈øtroyed by a fire, Feb. 8, 1756; much damaged by fire Feb. 14, 1758; again May 14, 1766; again Dec. 27, 1767.
Bru≈ø≈øels greatly damaged by a fire, and the ducal palace con≈øumed, Jan. 31, 1730.
Burwell, in Cambridge≈øhire, England, had a barn with 160 per≈øons in it, ≈øet fire to by carele≈øne≈øs, when every ≈øoul, except ≈øix, peri≈øhed in the flames, Sept. 8, 1727.

CALLAO, in Peru, de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, Nov. 1746, when all the inhabitants peri≈øhed except one man, who was ≈øtanding on an eminence, and to who≈øe relief the ≈øea providentially threw a boat.
Carl≈øcrone, Ru≈ø≈øia, had 1087 hou≈øes, two churches, all the merchants hou≈øes except two, and all their magazines de≈øtroyed by fire, June 17, 1790.
Carolina greatly damaged by a ≈øtorm 1722 and 1728.
Ceuta, in Barbary, had 200 hou≈øes blown down by a ≈øtorm, Feb. 1752.
Chamber≈øburgh, Penn≈øylvania, damaged by fire, Aug. 1, 1793.
Charle≈øtown, New England, greatly damaged by a ≈øtorm, 1761; burnt by the Briti≈øh troops, June 17, 1775.

Charle≈øtown, South Carolina, a hurricane at, and mo≈øt of the town con≈øumed by fire, 1699; half laid in ruins by a fire Nov. 1740; infe≈øted and much di≈øtre≈ø≈øed with worms, June 1751; de≈øtroyed by a hurricane, Sept. 15, 1753; had 250 dwelling hou≈øes, be≈øides out hou≈øes burnt, to the amount of 444,000 dollars, Jan. 15, 1778.
Chelm, in Poland, had 268 dwelling hou≈øes, and 107 ware hou≈øes de≈øtroyed by a fire, May 4, 1788.
Che≈øter, England, nearly de≈øtroyed by an accidental fire 1471: a great number of people killed by an accidental explo≈øion of gun powder, Nov. 5, 1722.
Chigi, a principality in Italy, had a fire which extended upwards of 12 miles, not leaving the ve≈øtige of a tree or even a vine, Aug. 1788. The cau≈øe was unknown.
Chili, almo≈øt the whole kingdom of, ≈øwallowed up by an earthquake, together with its capital St. Jago, 1730.
Cologne, Germany, received great damage by a flood, and had its bridge, with 100 per≈øons, be≈øides carts, &c. carried away, Dec. 1, 1747.
Colo≈ø≈øus of Rhodes, which weighed 720,000 lbs. weight, thrown down by an earthquake, 214 B. C.

Con≈øtantinople had above 12000 hou≈øes and 7000 inhabitants de≈øtroyed by a fire, Sept. 27, 1729; again which burnt five days, May 31, 1745; again which de≈øtroyed 12,000 hou≈øes, Jan. 29, 1750; again which con≈øumed about 10,000 in June following; 7000 per≈øons killed by the plague, 1751; nearly de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, and 3000 inhabitants killed, Sept. 2, 1754; 500 hou≈øes burnt 1756; con≈øiderable havoc made by fires in 1761, 1765, 1767, 1769, and 1771;
600 hou≈øes were burnt Feb. 19, 1782; and 7000 on the 10th June following; had 10,000 hou≈øes burnt Aug. 5, 1784; and in the year 1791, ≈øome time between March and July, there were no le≈øs than 32,000 hou≈øes de≈øtroyed.
Copenhagen burnt 1778, when 77 ≈øtreets were de≈øtroyed. Its palace totally con≈øumed by fire, December 1794.
Corah, Da ‚Ä¢ han and Abiram ≈øwallowed up by the earth, 1489 B. C.
Crediton in Devon≈øhire, England, had 460 hou≈øes de≈øtroyed by a fire, Aug. 14, 1753.
Crementz in Hungary, totally de≈øtroyed by a fire, 1777.
Con≈øtadt, near Peter≈øburgh, Ru≈ø≈øia, greatly damaged by a fire, 1791.
Cuba i≈øland damaged by an earthquake, 1530; again by an earthquake and ≈øtorm of rain, June 21, 1791, when 3000 per≈øons and 11,700 cattle peri≈øhed.
DAMAS, in Barbary, nearly de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, with 60,000 inhabitants, Dec. 3, 1759.
Danbury, Connecticut, burnt by the Briti≈øh, with large quantities of Continental ≈øtores, April 26, 1777; much damaged by lightning, July 6, 1793.
Deerfield, Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, burnt, and the inhabitants carried off as pri≈øoners, by the French and Indians, Feb. 1703.
Delaware river, a great flood in, which ≈øwept away ≈øeveral dwelling hou≈øes ≈øituated on the low grounds about the falls, 1692.
Delft in Holland, nearly de≈øtroyed by a fire, 1536.
Deluge of Ducalion, in The≈ø≈øaly, 1529 B. C.
‚Äî the general, threatened, in the year of the world 1546, i. e. 2348 before Chri≈øt, Noah being then about 600 years old, and continued 377 days. Noah left the ark Dec. 18, 2347 B. C.
Diana, the temple of, at Ephe≈øus, burnt 1148 B. C.
Domingo St. the i≈øle of, nearly de≈øtroyed, and the town of Port au Prince almo≈øt con≈øumed by the revolting negroes, Oct. Nov. and Dec. 1791.
Drury Lane theatre, London, with near 60 hou≈øes de≈øtroyed by a fire, Jan. 1672.
Dublin Hou≈øe of Commons, &c. de≈øtroyed by fire, Feb. 27, 1792.

EARTHQUAKE, one in A≈øia, which overturned 12 cities 17; Herculaneum buried by one 79; four cities in A≈øia, two in Greece, and three in Galatia, overturned 107. Antioch de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, 115; one ≈øwallowed up Nicodemia and ≈øeveral other cities, 120; one in Macedonia ≈øwallowed up 150 cities, 357; a terrible one, with an inundation, when 50,000 per≈øons were de≈øtroyed at Alexandria, July 1, 365; one which continued from September to November, and ≈øwallowed up ≈øeveral cities in Europe, 394; one which ≈øwallowed up ≈øeveral villages in the neighbourhood of Cybyra, 417; one which de≈øtroyed Antioch, Sept. 14, 458; one at Con≈øtantinople, which la≈øted 40 days, and overturned ≈øeveral edifices, 480; another at Antioch, which de≈øtroyed 4800 inhabitants, 528; one which ≈øhook France, Germany, and Italy, and threw down St. Paul's at Rome, April 801; one throughout all England, which was afterwards followed by a ≈øcarcity, 1090; one which ≈øwallowed up the city of Catania, and more than 1500 hundred ≈øouls, 1137; in Hungary and England, 1179; one at Calabria in Sicily, when a city and its inhabitants were lo≈øt in the Adriatic ≈øea, 1186; the greate≈øt ever known in England, Nov. 14, 1318; a dreadful one in Germany, 1346; a dreadful one at Li≈øbon, which continued eight days, overthrew 1500 hou≈øes, and killed 30,000 per≈øons, Feb. 1531; a whole province in China was, in one moment, ab≈øorbed into the earth, and all the towns and inhabitants buried in an immen≈øe lake of water, 1556; one in Naples and Sicily, which ≈øwallowed up ≈øeveral towns and 30,000 per≈øons, 1638, one in
Chili, when ≈øeveral whole mountains ≈øunk into the earth, one after another, 1646; 100,000 people peri≈øhed by an earthquake in Sicily, Jan. 1693; Palermo, in Sicily, nearly de≈øtroyed, and 6000 per≈øons lo≈øt their lives, Sept. 2, 1726; in New, Jer≈øey Nov. 1726 and 1732; again Dec. 7, 1737, Nov. 18, 1755, and Oct. 30, 1763; a remarkable one at Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, and other places in New England, Oct. 29, 1727; the whole of the kingdom of Chili ≈øwallowed up, and al≈øo St. Jago, 1730; four provinces in China ≈øwallowed up July 31, 1731; in Calabria in Sicily, when the territory of Nova Ca≈øa ≈øunk 29 feet without de≈øtroying a building, April 18, 1733; in Ireland, which de≈øtroyed five churches and upwards of 100 hou≈øes, Aug. 1734; one in the beginning of the pre≈øent century, which laid wa≈øte the whole country of Peru in a quarter of an hour, 300 leagues long and 90 wide; a terrible one at Lima, which entirely de≈øtroyed that city, and 5000 per≈øons lo≈øt their lives; there were 74 churches, 14 mona≈øteries, and 15 ho≈øpitals thrown down, and the lo≈øs in effects reckoned immen≈øe. This earthquake continued from Oct. 27, to Nov. 20, 1746, and extended to Callao, which was al≈øo de≈øtroyed; in London Feb. 8, and March 8, 1750, and in ≈øeveral other places in the ≈øouth of England, April 2, 1750; Grand Cairo had two-thirds of the hou≈øes, and 40,000 inhabitants ≈øwallowed up, Sept. 2, 1754; the city of Quito, in Peru, de≈øtroyed April 24, 1755; a terrible one Nov. 1, 1755, which did con≈øiderable damage at Oporto in Portugal, and Seville in Spain, but more particularly at Li≈øbon, where, in about eight minutes, mo≈øt of the hou≈øes, and 50,000 inhabitants were de≈øtroyed; the cities of Coimbra and Bruga ≈øuffered, and St. Ubes was ≈øwallowed up; the calamities occa≈øioned by this earthquake were immen≈øe, as it extended no le≈øs than 5000 miles; at the Azores i≈ølands, when 10,000 were buried in the ruins, and the i≈øland divided into two, July 9, 1757: at Bourdeaux in France, Aug. 11, 1758; Truxillo in Peru, was ≈øwallowed up by one Nov. 1759; at Martinico, Aug. 1767, when 1600
per≈øons lo≈øt their lives; Guatimala in New Spain, entirely ≈øwallowed up, and many thou≈øand inhabitants peri≈øhed, Dec. 15, 1773; at Tauris in Per≈øia, when 15,000 hou≈øes were thrown down, and great part of the inhabitants peri≈øhed, March 3, 1780; great part of Calabria in the i≈øland of Sicily was de≈øtroyed, and 30,000 people lo≈øt their lives, Feb. 25, 1783; another in the ≈øame i≈øland did great damage 1784; one in the North of England, Aug. 11, 1786; in Mexico, and in other parts of New Spain, April 18, 1787; in Scotland Oct. 1791; a ≈ølight ≈øhock perceived in Penn≈øylvania, early in 1792.
Edinburgh burnt, 1544.
Egg I≈øland, in the river St. Lawrence, eight Engli≈øh frigates wrecked upon, and 1000 men peri≈øhed, Aug. 23, 1711.
E ‚Ä¢ erghan, on the confines of Armenia, de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, with 6000 inhabitants, July 18, 1784.
FAIRFIELD, town of, in Connecticut, burnt by the Briti≈øh, July 7, 1779.
Falmouth, in New England, de≈øtroyed by the Briti≈øh, Oct. 18, 1775.

Famine, which la≈øted ≈øeven years, 1708 B. C.; at Rome, when the di≈øtre≈øs was ≈øo great that many people threw them≈øelves into the Tiber, and were drowned, 440 B. C.; in Britain, ≈øo that the wretched inhabitants were glad to eat the barks of trees, A. D. 272; one in Scotland, when thou≈øands of the inhabitants were ≈øtarved, 306; in England and Wales, when 40,000 people peri≈øhed, 310; all over Britain, 325; at Con≈øtantinople, 446; in Italy, when parents eat their children, 450; in Scotland, 576; all over England, Wales, and Scotland, 739; another in Wales, 747; in Wales and Scotland, 792; again in Scotland, 803, and in 823; a ≈øevere one in Wales, 836; in Scotland which la≈øted four years, 954; famines were in England, 864, 974, 976, 1005; in England and France
from 1193 to 1195; in England 1251, 1315, 1318, 1335, 1348; in England and France, called the dear ≈øummer, 1353; in England 1389 and 1348; in Scotland from 1695 to 1698, when thou≈øands peri≈øhed, and according to a writer,Mr. Fletcher. of the≈øe times, the di≈øtre≈øs was ≈øo great, that 200,000 people were begging from door to door; great ≈øcarcity in Scotland and Ireland, 1783, when the poor ≈øuffered greatly; famine in Paris, and divers parts of France, 1789; great ≈øcarcity at pre≈øent (1795) in Britain, Poland, and divers parts of Europe.
Flu≈øhing, in Zealand, damaged by fire, and the prince of Orange's hou≈øe burnt, Jan. 1749.

Fog, a, ≈øo remarkable in London, that ≈øeveral chairmen mi≈øtook their way in St. James's park, and fell with their fares into the canal; many per≈øons fell into Fleetditch; and con≈øiderable damage was done on the Thames, Jan. 1, 1729.
‚Äî a remarkable, in Long I≈øland, which ≈øeemed to be ≈øent by Divine Providence to cover the retreat of the American army, after the battle of Flatbu≈øh, Aug. 27, 1776.
‚Äî at Am≈øterdam, ≈øo great that 230 per≈øons peri≈øhed by falling into the canals, Jan. 10, 1790.

Fro≈øts, remarkable; a ≈øevere one in Scotland, which la≈øted for 14 weeks, 359; the ≈øea of Pontus, and that between Con≈øtantinople and Scutari, 401; ≈øo ≈øevere a fro≈øt all over Britain, that the rivers were frozen up for above two months, 508: one ≈øo great, that the Danube was quite frozen over, 558; carriages were u≈øed on the Adriatic ≈øea, 859; the Mediterranean ≈øea was frozen over and pa≈ø≈øable in carts in 860; mo≈øt of the rivers in England frozen for two months, 908; the Thames frozen for 13 weeks, 923; a fro≈øt in England on mid≈øummer day ≈øo vehement, that the corn and fruits were de≈øtroyed, 1035; the Mediterranean ≈øea was frozen over, and the merchants pa≈øt their merchandize in carts, 1234; the Cattegat ≈øea, between Norway and
Denmark was frozen 1294; the ≈øea from Sweden to Gothland frozen 1296; the Baltic was pa≈ø≈øable for foot pa≈ø≈øengers and hor≈øemen for ≈øix weeks, in 1323; again in 1402; the ≈øea between Con≈øtantinople and I≈økodar was pa≈ø≈øable on ice, in 1620; a great fro≈øt in England for three months, with heavy ≈ønows, from December to March 1709; again, when a fair was held on the Thames in 1716; a very ≈øevere fro≈øt in Ru≈ø≈øia, 1747; in America ≈øo ≈øevere in the winter of 1780 and 1781, that in January the pa≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ge between New York and State ‚Ä¢ I≈øland was practicable for the heavie≈øt cannon; in England January 1789, when the Thames was cro≈ø≈øed on the ice oppo≈øite the cu≈øtom hou≈øe, the tower, &c. This fro≈øt was at the ≈øame time general in Europe, particularly in Holland; fro≈øt and ≈ønow, with hail, in different parts of England at mid≈øummer 1791; and in Italy and Spain in December following; the mo≈øt remarkable fro≈øt in Europe which has happened in this century, was in the pre≈øent winter 1794 and 1795, when the Zuyder ≈øea in Holland was frozen over, a circum≈øtance which has not happened in the memory of man. This fro≈øt was al≈øo inten≈øely ≈øevere in Britain, Ireland, &c.
GABEL in Bohemia, a large town, totally de≈øtroyed by fire, May 11, 1788.
Gera, near Leip≈øic in Germany, totally de≈øtroyed by a fire Sept. 18, 1780.
Gibraltar nearly de≈øtroyed by a ≈øtorm, Feb. 3, 1766.
Goodwin ≈øands, on the coa≈øt of Kent, in England, occa≈øioned by an inundation of the ≈øea, 1100.
Gottenburgh had 120 hou≈øes de≈øtroyed by fire, March 2, 1792.
Grand Cairo nearly de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, and 40,000 inhabitants lo≈øt, June 2, 1754.
Greenwich ho≈øpital, London, had its chapel and one quadrangle of the whole building de≈øtroyed by a fire, Jan. 2, 1779.
Grenada, a dreadful fire there, by which the town of St. George was entirely con≈øumed, Nov. 1, 1772.
Groton, town of, in Connecticut, burnt by Benedict Arnold, Sept. 6, 1781.
Guatimala, in New Spain, much damaged by an inundation, Sept. 1541; entirely ≈øwallowed up by an earthquake. Dec. 15, 1773.
HAIL, a remarkable ≈øhower of, at Philadelphia, accompanied with thunder and lightning, May 22, 1794; ≈øeveral hail-≈øtones mea≈øured from two to two and a half inches in circumference. See Storms.
Herculaneum, in Italy, totally overwhelmed by an eruption of Mount Ve≈øuvius, Nov. 1, 79: its ruins di≈øcovered 1747; 150 volumes of MSS. found there, 1754.
Honiton, in Devon≈øhire, England, nearly de≈øtroyed by a fire, July 19, 1747; 140 hou≈øes burnt there, 1765; 37 hou≈øes de≈øtroyed there, May 1790.

INUNDATIONS, one of the ≈øea, which overflowed 4000 acres of Earl Goodwin's e≈øtate in Kent, England, ≈øince called the Goodwin ≈øands, 1100; one in Holland, when the ≈øea broke in at Dert, and drowned 72 villages and 100,000 people; another in 1421, by which the Zuyder ≈øea was formed; one in Catalonia, Spain, from continued rains, attended with a ≈øtorm, which de≈øtroyed more than 50,000 per≈øons, 1617; one at New-ca≈øtle on Tyne, in England, by which upwards of 120 per≈øons were drowned, 1633; one in York≈øhire, England, in which a rock vi≈øibly opened, and water was thrown into the air, to the height of an ordinary church ≈øteeple, 1686; an inundation of the Delaware, which ≈øwept away ≈øeveral dwelling hou≈øes, 1692; in Zealand, when the ≈øea broke the dykes, and covered the whole country with water, 1300 people lo≈øt their lives; at Naples, where it carried away a whole village, and drowned 200 of the inhabitants, Nov. 10, 1773;
in different parts of Germany and in England, in the fall of 1785, when ≈øome thou≈øands had their hou≈øes and property de≈øtroyed; in Spain, Sept. 17, 1787, when 2000 people lo≈øt their lives, and all the buildings of ≈øeveral villages were ≈øwept away by the currents from the mountains. A terrible inundation by the Liffey in Ireland, which did con≈øiderable damage in Dublin and its environs, Nov. 12, 1787; of the North river at New-York, which con≈øiderably damaged the docks, &c. Sept. 1788; dreadful inundations in Scotland and the North of England, March 1795.
JAGO St. a ≈øtorm at, which did much damage, and the hail ≈øtones were as large as oranges, July, 1772.

Jamaica, an earthquake at, June 7, 1692, which ≈øhook the whole i≈øland to the foundation, and totally de≈øtroyed the city Port Royal, ≈øo as not to leave in one quarter not even the ≈ømalle≈øt ve≈øtige ≈øtanding; a dreadful hurricane here, Augu≈øt 30, 1722; again Sept. 1, 1734, and Oct. 1744; another which did much damage, Aug. 10, 1751; October 3, 1780. This i≈øland was greatly damaged by a dreadful hurricane, which almo≈øt overwhelmed the little ≈øea-port town of Savannah la Mer, and great part of the adjacent country. It al≈øo overturned almo≈øt every hou≈øe, and killed a great number of people; another did con≈øiderable damage July 30, 1784; and again in 1790. Five ≈øhips, three brigs, a ≈ønow, two ≈øchooners, many wharves, &c. de≈øtroyed by an extraordinary ≈øwell of the ≈øea, Oct. 21. 1793.
John's Town, St. Antigua, de≈øtroyed by a ≈øtorm, Aug. 17, and 31, 1772; by fire 1769.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, greatly damaged by fire, Feb. 9, 1782.
‚Äî in Ul≈øter county, New York, burnt by the Briti≈øh, 1777.

Kitts St. alias St. Chri≈øtopher's, damaged by a ≈øtorm, and 30 ≈øhips left on its coa≈øt, 1733; greatly damaged by fire, 1768; ≈øuffered an immen≈øe lo≈øs by ≈øtorm, and the town of Ba≈ø≈øaterre de≈øtroyed by fire, Sept. 5, 1776.
LIGHTNING, ≈øee Storms.

Lima, a terrible earthquake there, 1586; another, Oct. 28, 1746, which continued from Oct. 27, to Nov. 20, by which 50,000 per≈øons lo≈øt their lives, and 74 churches, 14 mona≈øteries, and 15 ho≈øpitals were thrown down.
Li≈øbon de≈øtroyed by an earthquake, 1531, again Nov. 1, 1755, when in a few minutes mo≈øt of the hou≈øes, and 50,000 inhabitants were de≈øtroyed; con≈øiderable damage done by one, Nov. 27, 1791.
Liverpool, England, much damaged by a ≈øtorm, June 29, 1789.

London, great part of it de≈øtroyed by fire, 982; a fire on London bridge, which de≈øtroyed 2000 per≈øons, July 10, 1212; the remarkable fire there, which commenced Sept. 2, 1666, ea≈øtward from the monument erected to perpetuate its memory, at the di≈øtance of 202 feet (the height of that column). It began about midnight, and being driven on by a high wind, not only wa≈øted the adjacent parts, but al≈øo very remote places, with incredible fury. Plague, almo≈øt the whole world vi≈øited by one 767 B. C.; one ≈øo dreadful at Rome, as to carry off 10,000 people in a day, 78; a terrible one all over Europe, A≈øia, and Africa, which la≈øted near fifty years, 577; in England, which carried off 30,000 people, 772; in Scotland, which ≈øwept away 40,000 inhabitants, 954; in England 1025, 1247, and 1347; in Germany, which cut off 93,000 people, 1348; in France and England very dreadful, 1362: again 1379; in London, which killed 30,000 per≈øons, 1407; again 1477 and in 1499, which cut off 30,000 people; throughout England ≈øo terrible, that half the people died, 1517; in London, which carried off 30,578 per≈øons, 1604; at Con≈øtantinople, when 200,000 per≈øons died, 1611; at London, which carried off 35,417 inhabitants, 1625; again 1631; at Lyons, in France, which carried off 60,000 people, 1632. The great plague, as it was emphatically called, at London, was brought there in ≈øome Levant goods, which came from Holland, about the clo≈øe of the year 1664. The≈øe goods were carried
to a hou≈øe near Drury Lane, where they were fir≈øt opened, and here two Frenchmen died in a few days after. Its further progre≈øs was checked by a hard fro≈øt, which ≈øet in this winter, and continued till the month of March 1665, when its virulence again revived. As ≈øoon as the magi≈øtrates ≈øound that the contagion extended into different parts of the city, an order was i≈ø≈øued for ≈øhutting up infected hou≈øes, to ≈øtop the communication of the di≈øorder. The≈øe hou≈øes had red cro≈ø≈øes painted on the doors, with this in≈øcription, Lord, have mercy upon us! and watchmen were placed before them, to hand the afflicted, nece≈ø≈øaries and medicines, and to prevent them from coming abroad, until 40 days after their recovery. But notwith≈øtanding every caution, the contagion continued to ≈øpread; ≈øo that in the fir≈øt week of July the bills of mortality ro≈øe to 725; the next week to 1089; the third week to 1843; and the next week to 2010: in Augu≈øt the deaths amounted to between 8 and 10,000 per week. Towards the fall, the di≈øorder became le≈øs frequent, and yielded to the force of medicine; and in the winter this great enemy of mankind received an effectual check. The regi≈øters were, however, very inaccurately kept; and it was the opinion of eye-witne≈ø≈øes, that at lea≈øt 100,000 peri≈øhed by the plague.

The great plague at Mar≈øeilles, in France, was brought there from Syria, in May 1720; its progre≈øs was at fir≈øt extremely ≈ølow, and the phy≈øicians, who had opened ≈øome dead bodies, and declared the dangerous nature of the di≈øorder, were in≈øulted by the rabble: nor was it, till the end of July, that the inhabitants began to perceive their danger. then adopted to prevent the ≈øpreading of the di≈øtemper, as well as the progre≈øs of famine, which, likewi≈øe, began to ≈øtare them in the face. On the 21≈øt of Augu≈øt the number of dead increa≈øed ≈øo prodigiou≈øly, that the magi≈øtrates found it impracticable to get them carried out of town to be thrown into the pits: they were, therefore, under the nece≈ø≈øity of getting the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the galley ≈ølaves, and having them buried in the vaults of the churchyards. YELLOW fever, in Philadelphia, which committed great deva≈øtation, 1699; the We≈øt Indies, 1732, 1739, 1745, and 1748; in Philadelphia again, when the di≈øorder raged with great violence, in the fall of 1762; in New York 1791, it prevailed in a part of Water-≈øtreet, and according to the ≈øphere of its action, was exceedingly fatal. It began in Augu≈øt, and continued till the middle of September, when it totally di≈øappeared; during which ≈øhort time it cut off between 2 and 300 people. It began in Philadelphia 1793, and committed dreadful havoc. As many of
our readers may not have had an opportunity of peru≈øing the volumes which have been written on that di≈øorder, we ≈øhall here ≈øubjoin the following ≈øhort acaccount, which, we tru≈øt, will prove acceptable to our readers.

This di≈øorder made its fir≈øt appearance towards the latter end of July, in a lodging hou≈øe in North Water≈øtreet; and for a few weeks ≈øeemed entirely confined to that vicinity. Hence it was generally ≈øuppo≈øed to have been imported, and not generated in the city. This was the opinion of Doctors Currie, Cathrall, and many others. It was however combated by Dr. Benjamin Ru≈øh, who a≈ø≈øerts, that the contagion was generated from the ≈øtench of a cargo of damaged coffee, which had been landed near the ≈øame place where it fir≈øt made its appearances, on a ≈øuppo≈øition that vegetable putrifaction might produce ≈øuch a di≈øorder. For this opinion he has given his rea≈øons at large, in a volume of which he has lately publi≈øhed the ≈øecond edition.
As the mo≈øt eminent phy≈øicians have differed on this ≈øubject, we ≈øhall not offend by hazarding an opinion. To tho≈øe who wi≈øh for particular information, we refer to their re≈øpective writings.

But from whatever fountain we trace this poi≈øoned ≈øtream, it has de≈øtroyed the lives of many thou≈øands‚Äî and many of tho≈øe of the mo≈øt di≈øtingui≈øhed worth. Its characteri≈øtic or leading ≈øymptoms were ≈øudden debility in the voluntary powers, oppre≈ø≈øive pain, giddine≈øs, ≈øen≈øe of fullne≈øs and di≈øtention in the ve≈ø≈øels of the fore part of the head, and an oppre≈ø≈øive weight about the heart and lungs, accompanied with great angui≈øh and re≈øtle≈ø≈øne≈øs. During the month of Augu≈øt, the funerals amounted to upwards of three hundred. The di≈øea≈øe had then reached the central ≈øtreets of the city, and began to ≈øpread on all ≈øides with the greate≈øt rapidity. In September its malignance increa≈øed amazingly. Fear pervaded the ≈øtoute≈øt heart; flight became general, and terror was depicted on every countenance. In this month 1400 more were added to the li≈øt of mortality. The contagion w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtill progre≈ø≈øive, and towards the
end of the month, 90 and 100 died daily. Until the middle of October, this mighty de≈øtroyer went on with increa≈øing havoc. From the 1≈øt to the 17th, upwards of 1400 fell as victims to the tremendous malady. From the 17th to the 30th the mortality gradually decrea≈øed. In the whole month, however, the dead amounted to upwards of 2000‚Äîa dreadful number, if we con≈øider that at this time near one half of the inhabitants had fled. Before the di≈øorder became ≈øo terrible, the garlic which many chewed as a preventative, could be ≈ømelled at ≈øeveral yards di≈øtance; whil≈øt others hoped to avoid infection by a recour≈øe to ≈ømelling bottles, handkerchiefs dipped in vinegar, camphor bags, &c. ≈øo that few individuals could be ≈øeen in the ≈øtreets without one or other of the≈øe applied to his no≈øtrils.

At la≈øt, however, experience had proved that the≈øe were inefficacious. A reliance on Divine Providence ≈øucceeded, and in the mo≈øt terrible ≈øtage of the di≈øorder the citizens di≈øcovered the mo≈øt decent fortitude and the greate≈øt re≈øignation. The≈øe imaginary preventatives were therefore thrown a≈øide.

From the 1≈øt to the 7th of November, the mortality gradually decrea≈øed. On the 9th, the burials, which had hitherto been ≈øo exceedingly numerous, were reduced to ≈øix. The fugitive citizens now began to return, and the ≈øtreets re≈øumed their wonted life and activity.

During this awful calamity, as has been already ob≈øerved, terror and di≈ømay generally pervaded the citizens. Some were found, however, who, at the ri≈øque of their own lives, were highly in≈øtrumental in ≈øaving the lives of their fellow creatures. An ho≈øpital was erected at Bu≈øhhill, at the di≈øtance of about one mile from the inhabited part of the city. Thither the infected were ≈øent in great numbers, but from? want of cleanline≈øs and good order, the ho≈øpital and the grave were nearly the ≈øame thing.

A committee had been appointed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the guardians of the poor in the legal di≈øcharge of their duty. It was one of the fir≈øt objects of their care to remedy this evil. To ≈øearch into the horrors of this di≈ømal receptacle
required the fortitude of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Howard. Men, however, ≈øtepped forth, and voluntarily undertook the arduous ta≈øk. Stephen Girard, a native of France, a wealthy merchant of this city, and Peter Helm, a native of Philadelphia, both members of the committee, offered their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. Thanks to Heaven! their invaluable lives were pre≈øerved, and their generous labours crowned with ≈øucce≈øs. The poor now no longer con≈øidered Bu≈øhhill as the anti-chamber of the grave; but as a humane provi≈øion for the nece≈ø≈øitous ≈øick: and now many recovered.

So great a mortality of cour≈øe left a great number of orphans in very de≈øtitute circum≈øtances. Here again was a large field of labour open for the benevolent. The children were to be provided with nur≈øes, provi≈øions, and other accommodations. The committee, however, to their former burthens undertook this, and procured the Loganian library, which was fitted up as an orphan-hou≈øe, where about two hundred children were admitted, ≈øixty of whom were infants.

The accumulating expences of this in≈øtitution, with that of Bu≈øhhill and many others, obviou≈øly required con≈øiderable ≈øums of money. Liberal contributions were ≈øent from different quarters, amounting in the whole to 29,085 dollars.
During this melancholy period the city lo≈øt ten of her mo≈øt valuable phy≈øicians, and mo≈øt of the others were ≈øick at different times. The number of deaths in all, amounted to about 5000.

To omit recording the names of tho≈øe by who≈øe benevolent exertions, under Divine Providence, the city was ≈øaved from utter de≈øtruction, would be highly culpable in any annali≈øt. To perpetuate the fal≈øely acquired fame of tho≈øe who have made them≈øelves con≈øpicuous by butchering thou≈øands of their fellow-creatures, ≈øtatues have been often erected; but what rewards, what ≈øtatues, what language can ≈øufficiently de≈øcribe the merits of tho≈øe, who, at the imminent danger of their own invaluable lives, have ≈øo eminently conduced to the ≈øafety of a great city? In March 1794,
the citizens of Philadelphia and its ≈øuburbs a≈ø≈øembled at the City Hall to expre≈øs their gratitude, and appointed a committee, con≈øi≈øting of Thomas M'Kean, Alexander James Dallas, Anthony Morris, Jonathan Bayard Smith, John Swanwick, Charles Biddle, and William Rogers, to draw out an in≈øtrument expre≈ø≈øive thereof, which, as it well expre≈ø≈øes the ≈øentiments of the Philadelphians towards their deliverers, we ≈øhall here lay it before our readers.

"Whereas it hath plea≈øed the Supreme Ruler and Governor of the univer≈øe to permit, during the months of Augu≈øt, September, and October la≈øt, a mo≈øt dreadful vi≈øitation, or epidemic malady, to afflict the city and liberties of Philadelphia in ≈øuch manner, that it is ≈øuppo≈øed not le≈øs than 5000 of the inhabitants thereof have fallen victims to the ≈øame; and whereas the following citizens of Philadelphia,
Matthew Clark≈øon,
Stephen Girard,
John Letchworth,
John Haworth,
Thomas Savery,
Henry Defore≈øt,
Jonathan D. Serjeant,
Caleb Lownes,
Peter Helm,
James Kerr,
James Swain,
Jacob Witman,
John Connely,
Daniel Offley,
Thomas Wi≈øtar,
I≈ørael I≈ørael,
James Shar≈øwood,
Matthew Carey,
Samuel Benge,
Andrew Adgate, and
Jo≈øeph In≈økeep,
totally di≈øregarding their own per≈øonal pre≈øervation, and only intent on arre≈øting the progre≈øs of the malignant di≈øorder, with a magnanimity and patrioti≈øm meriting the highe≈øt eulogiums, ≈øtood forth, and by every generous and endearing exertion, pre≈øerved the lives of many of their fellow-citizens from death, by conveying them to a ≈øuitable ho≈øpital, which they had provided at Bu≈øhhill for their reception, where, under the meritorious exertions and peculiar care of Stephen Girard and Peter Helm, two of the citizens above named, every po≈ø≈øible comfort was provided
for the ≈øick, and decent burials for tho≈øe whom their efforts could not pre≈øerve from the ravages of the prevailing di≈øtemper; in order, therefore, to perpetuate the memory of ≈øuch di≈øtingui≈øhed u≈øefulne≈øs to di≈øtant times, and to ≈øerve as an example and encouragement to others to emulate the like beneficent virtues, ≈øhould it ever unfortunately again become nece≈ø≈øary to practice them,‚Äîthe citizens of Philadelphia, &c. do, by this in≈øtrument, pre≈øent to the above named
Matthew Clark≈øon,
Caleb Lownes,
Thomas Wi≈øtar,
Stephen Girard,
Peter Helm,
I≈ørael I≈ørael,
John Letchworth,
James Kerr,
James Sharwood,
John Haworth,
James Swaine,
Matthew Carey,
Thomas Savery,
Jacob Witman,
Samuel Benge,
Henry Defore≈øt, and
John Connely,
their mo≈øt cordial, grateful, and fraternal thanks for their benevolent and patriotic exertions in relieving the mi≈øeries of ≈øuffering humanity, on the late mournful occa≈øion; and as Andrew Adgate, Jonathan D. Sarjeant, Jo≈øeph In≈økeep, and Daniel Offley, unfortunately fell victims to their generous exertions for the pre≈øervation of the inhabitants, it is hoped, that their great ≈øervices will be held in everla≈øting remembrance by the citizens to who≈øe welfare they ≈øo nobly devoted them≈øelves, even unto death; and that this will be evidenced, on all proper occa≈øions, in a ≈øuitable attention to their ≈øurviving relatives.

"Ordered, That a copy of this in≈øtrument be duly engro≈ø≈øed upon parchment, ≈øigned by the chairman of the meeting, and pre≈øented to each of the per≈øons above named, and to the repre≈øentatives of the decea≈øed members of the committee, to remain with them as a memorial of the ≈øen≈øe their fellow citizens entertain of the ≈øervices rendered them during the late dreadful calamity."

It was al≈øo re≈øolved, that thanks ≈øhould be given to
William P. Spragues,

William San≈øom,
Ju≈øtinian Fox,
Amos Wicker≈øham,

Thomas Dob≈øon,

William Eckhard,
William Innis,
John Graham,

Daniel Daw≈øon,

who, as an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant committee, aided the later exertions of the committee of health, and that they be a≈ø≈øured the citizens retain a ju≈øt ≈øen≈øe of their meritorious conduct on that occa≈øion."

Neither ought the meritorious exertions of ≈øome others to be omitted. The conduct of Mrs. Saville, matron of the ho≈øpital at Bu≈øhhill, and of Mary Parvin, to whom the care of the orphans had been committed, was above all prai≈øe. The names of Richard Allen, William Gray, and Ab≈øalom Jones, three men of colour, ought likewi≈øe to be mentioned, who were ince≈ø≈øant in their labours in burying the dead, procuring nur≈øes for the ≈øick, &c.

The yellow fever again made its appearance in Philadelphia, about July 1794, but di≈øappeared after having ≈øacrificed a few lives: ≈øame year it raged greatly at Fell's point, near Baltimore. For the la≈øt three years it appears to have been prevalent in ≈øeveral of the We≈øt India i≈ølands.
York city, in England, with its cathedral and 39 churches, de≈øtroyed by a fire, June 3, 1137.

div.head: Pre≈øidents of Congre≈øs.
div.p: PEYTON Randolph, elected September 5, 1774, but being unable to ≈øerve on account of indi≈øpo≈øition, Henry Middleton was elected in his ≈øtead, October 22, 1774.

Peyton Randolph re-elected May 10, 1775, but being under the nece≈ø≈øity of returning home on bu≈øine≈øs, May 24, John Hancock of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts was unanimou≈øly cho≈øen to ≈øupply his placeMr. Randolph died October 23, 1775.. div.head: Memorable Accidents.
div.p: THE amphitheatre at Fidonia fell in and killed 50,000 people, A. D. 26; the ruins of it ≈øtill remain.
The town of Fleurus, in Italy, was buried by a part of the Alps falling on it, and 2200 per≈øons were killed, 1618.
The roof the church at Fearn, in Scotland, fell in during divine ≈øervice, and killed 60 per≈øons, October 19, 1742.
The Victory, a Briti≈øh man of war of 100 guns, war lo≈øt, with all her crew, October 1744.
Three Briti≈øh ≈øhips of war, with Sir Admiral Cloude≈øley Shovel, wrecked on the rocks of Scilly, and all peri≈øhed, October 1777.
A ≈øcaffold build for ≈øpectators to ≈øee Lord Lovat beheaded, at London, fell down, which killed ≈øeveral, and maimed a great many, 1704.
Bath ≈øtage waggon burnt on Sali≈øbury plain, England, with its valuable lading occa≈øioned by the wheels taking fire, May 20, 1758.
Prince George, a Briti≈øh ≈øhip of war, was burnt off Li≈øbon, when 458 of her crew peri≈øhed, Augu≈øt 11, 1758.

At the fire-works exhibited at Paris, in honour of the Dauphin's marriage, the pa≈ø≈øages being ≈øtopped up occa≈øioned ≈øuch a croud, that the people, ≈øeized with panic, trampled upon one another till they lay in heaps; a ≈øcaffold erected over the river al≈øo broke down, and nearly 1000 per≈øons lo≈øt their lives, April 21, 1770.
Twelve hundred and forty people were killed in the i≈øland of Java by an electrified cloud, 1772.
The Randolph, an American frigate of 36 guns, and 305 men, was blown up in an engagement with the Yarmouth, a Briti≈øh 64, and every per≈øon on board was drowned, except four, March 7, 1778.
The London Ea≈øt Indiaman run down by the Ru≈ø≈øel man of war, when ≈øhe funk, and 110 per≈øons peri≈øhed, December 28, 1778.
Bourbon les Baines, in Ba≈ø≈øigni, France, had the vault under the church give way during the celebration of ma≈øs, which occa≈øioned the death of 600 per≈øons, September 14, 1778.
The bridge at Puerta, St. Maria, near Cadiz, Spain, fell down as ≈øoon as fini≈øhed, while receiving the benediction, and killed ≈øeveral hundred per≈øons, February 22, 1779.

The Royal George, a Briti≈øh ≈øhip of 100 guns, being heeled to one ≈øide for the purpo≈øe of cleaning her bottom, and her lee ports not being ≈øhut, gave a ≈øudden lurch, and was in≈øtantly filled with water; by which misfortune Admiral Kempenfelt, by far the greater part of the crew, between 2 and 300 women, and a great many traders were drowned, June 28, 1782.
Montpellier at, in France, a booth, wherein a play was performing, fell, and killed 500 per≈øons, July 31, 1786.
Hal≈øewell Ea≈øt Indiaman wrecked near Portland, in England, when 100 people peri≈øhed, January 6, 1786.
Le Scipio, a French ≈øhip of 74 guns, got on fire at Leghorn, in Italy, and 200 of her crew peri≈øhed, November 26, 1794.
Several French ve≈ø≈øels of war were wrecked in the Engli≈øh channel, in con≈øequence of very ≈øevere ≈øtorms, in the winter of 1794 and 1795.

The Boyne, a Briti≈øh 98 gun ≈øhip, lying at Spithead, accidentally got on fire, May 1, 1795, and notwith≈øtanding every exertion to ≈øave her, was totally con≈øumed; ≈øeveral hundred ≈øeamen, a number of women, children, traders, &c. were either drowned or peri≈øhed in the flames.

div.head: Accidents occa≈øioned by Explo≈øions.
div.p: SIXTY hou≈øes blown up, including a tavern full of company, oppo≈øite Barking church, Tower-≈øtreet, London, by the accidental blowing up of ≈øome barrels of gunpowder at a ≈øhip-chandlers, January 4, 1649: a child in a cradle was found unhurt on the leads of the church.
Gravelines, France, had 3000 peopled killed by an explo≈øition of a magazine, 1654.
At Dublin, Ireland, above 100 men were killed by the blowing up of a magazine of 218 barrels of gunpowder, 1693.
Bremen, greatly damaged by an explo≈øion of gunpowder, when 1000 hou≈øes were de≈øtroyed, September 10, 1739.
Charle≈øton, South Carolina, greatly damaged by an explo≈øion, Augu≈øt 11, 1762.
Trinchinopoli, in the Ea≈øt Indies, blown up by the magazine of powder having taken fire, when 300 inhabitants lo≈øt their lives, 1772.
Abbeville, in France, nearly de≈øtroyed by an explo≈øion of gunpowder, when 150 of the inhabitants peri≈øhed, and 100 hou≈øes were de≈øtroyed, Nov. 1773.
Bre≈øcia, in Italy, nearly de≈øtroyed by an explo≈øion of gunpowder, Augu≈øt 28, 1779.
Civita Vecchia, in Italy, nearly de≈øtroyed by an explo≈øion, September 1779.
At Corfus, a magazine was de≈øtroyed by a fire, when 72,000 lbs. of powder, and 600 bomb-≈øhells blew up, and killed 180 men, March 11, 1789.

The powder mills in the plains de Granelis, France, were blown up, September 3, 1793, when the explo≈øion was ≈øo great, that windows were broken at the di≈øtance of three leagues, and nearly 1000 people were killed or wounded.

div.head: Remarkable Occurrences.
div.p: MOUNT Ve≈øuvius, in Italy, threw out ≈øuch a quantity of flame and ≈ømoke, that the air was darkened, and the cities of Pompeia and Herculaneum were overwhelmed by the burning lava, A. D. 79; (Herculaneum was di≈øcovered in 1737, and ≈øeveral curio≈øities have been dug up from time to time ≈øince that period.)
A column of fire appeared m the air, at Rome, for 30 days, 390.

The country of Pale≈øtine infe≈øted with ≈øuch ≈øwarms of locu≈øts, that they darkened the air; and after having devoured the fruits of the earth, and afterwards died, they cau≈øed a ≈øtench which occa≈øioned a pe≈øtilential fever, 406.

In the month of Augu≈øt 873, ≈øuch a prodigious ≈øwarm of large gra≈øs-hoppers ≈øettled upon the lands of France, that in one night they devoured every thing green, even to the leaves and bark of young trees; they died ≈øoon after, and their ≈øtench occa≈øioned a pe≈øtilential fever.

A prodigious number of ≈ønakes formed them≈øelves into two bodies, in a plain, near Tournay, in France, and fought with ≈øuch fury, that one of the parties was almo≈øt de≈øtroyed, and the other was afterwards killed by the pea≈øants, 1059.

At Oxenhall, near Darlington, England, the earth ≈øuddenly ro≈øe to an eminence re≈øembling a mountain, and remained ≈øo for ≈øeveral hours, when it ≈øuddenly ≈øunk in, with a tremendous noi≈øe, 1179.
Gulen river, in Norway, buried it≈øelf under ground, 1344, but bur≈øt out ≈øoon after, and de≈øtroyed 250 per≈øons, with ≈øeveral churches, hou≈øes, &c.

Markeley hill, near Hereford, England, was moved from its ≈øituation, February 17, 1751, and continued its motion for three days, during which time it carried
along with it the trees, hedges, and cattle on its ≈øurface, and in other re≈øpects did much damage.

In 1583, a ≈øimilar prodigy happened in Dorcet≈øhire, England, when a field of three acres, with the trees and fences, moved from thence, pa≈ø≈øed over another field, and ≈øettled at the di≈øtance of ≈øome miles from its original ≈øtation.
An unacountable darkne≈øs at noon-day in England, ≈øo that no per≈øon could ≈øee to read, January 12, 1679.
A great comet appeared in Europe, which continued from November 3, to March 9, following, and from its nearne≈øs to our earth, occa≈øioned much alarm, 1680.

In 1694, there was a remarkable eruption of Mount Ve≈øuvius, in Italy, which continued near a month, when burning matter was thrown out with ≈øo great force, that ≈øome of it fell at thirty miles di≈øtance, and a va≈øt quantity of melted mineral mixed with other matter, ran down like a river for three miles, carryng every thing before it which lay in its way.
Borge, a ≈øeat near Fredorick≈øtadt, in Norway, ≈øunk into an aby≈øs of 100 fathoms deep, which in≈øtantly became a lake. By this occurrence 14 per≈øons were drowned, and 240 head of cattles, 1702.
A great eruption of Mount Ve≈øuvius took place, which threw out ≈øuch quantities of cinders and a≈øhes, as to occa≈øion darkne≈øs at Naples at noon-day, 1767.

A body of light appeared in England, in the north ea≈øt quarter, which formed ≈øeveral columns, or pillars, and threw the people into great con≈øternation; it la≈øted from the evening of March the 6th, till three the next morning, 1715.

A fla≈øh of lightning penetrate the theatre at Venice, Italy, during the repre≈øentation which killed ≈øeveral people; it out the candles, melted a lady's gold watch-ca≈øe, the jewels in the ears of others, and ‚Ä¢ plit ≈øeveral diamonds, Augu≈øt 1769.
The planet Mercury pa≈ø≈øed over the ≈øun's di≈øk, vi≈øible to the naked eye, from twelve to two o'clock, at London, November 25, 1769.
Frequent explo≈øions of fire were ob≈øerved to proceed from We≈øt river mountain, ≈øtate of New Hamp≈øhire, 1730.

Solway mo≈øs, near Carli≈øle, in England, began to ≈øwell, owing to heavy rains, and upwards of 400 acres of it ro≈øe to ≈øuch a height above the level of the ground, that at la≈øt it rolled forwards like a torrent, and continued its cour≈øe above a mile, ≈øweeping along with it hou≈øes, trees, and every thing in its way; it then divided into i≈ølands of different extent, from one to ten feet, upon which were found hares, wild fowl, &c. It covered nearly 600 acres at Netherly, the place to which it moved, and in its progre≈øs de≈øtroyed 30 ≈ømall villages. It continued its motion from Saturday to Wedne≈øday, December 31, 1771.
The river Pever, in Glouce≈øter≈øhire, England, ≈øuddenly altered its cour≈øe, and ten acres of land, with every thing on its ≈øurface, were removed with the current, 1773.
When the American Army were defeated at the battle of Flat-Bu≈øh, Long I≈øland, a very thick fog ≈øaved them from being cut off in their retreat, Augu≈øt 28, 1776.
A remarkable dark day in New England, May 19, 1780.

In May 1783, a remarkable change was made in Poultney river, ≈øtate of Vermont, when it turned its cour≈øe ≈øuddenly to the north-ea≈øt, and by degrees wore a channel 60 feet drep, leaving its former channel perfectly dry.
A large plantation in the i≈øland of Barbadoes, with all its buildings, de≈øtroyed by the lands removing from a former ≈øeat to another, and covering every thing in its way, October 16, 1784.
An unaccountable dark day at Quebec, on Sunday, September 16, 1785.
The ground at Brixton, in Norfolk, England, ≈øunk near 30 feet, for a very con≈øiderable extent, June 1788.

Ethelred II. brother of Edward, 979.
Swain, from Denmark, after having ≈øubdued the country, was proclaimed king, 1013.

Canute, ≈øon of Swain, 1014. This prince was ≈øoon after forced to leave the kingdom, and Ethelred, who had been obliged to retire, again rea≈ø≈øumed the reins of government, at the invitation of his ≈øubjects.
Edmund Iron≈øide was crowned, April 1016, but was ≈øoon after defeated by Canute, who again obtained the ≈øovereignty.
Harold, ≈øon of Canute, began to reign 1036.
Hardicanute, his brother, ≈øucceeded him, 1041.
Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, 1042.
Harold II. ≈øon of the earl of Kent, 1066.

William I. duke of Normandy, a de≈øcendant of Canute, invaded the kingdom, and defeated the Engli≈øh at the battle of Ha≈øtings, October 11, 1066, when Harold was ≈ølain, and William a≈ø≈øumed the title of Conqueror.
William II. ≈øon of the former, began to reign September 27, 1087.
Henry I. brother of the former, Augu≈øt 5, 1100.
Maude, daughter of Henry I. 1126.
Stephen crowned, 1135.
Henry II. grand≈øon of Henry I. 1135.
Richard I. ≈øon of Henry II. 1189.
John, his brother, 1199.
Henry III. crowned, 1216.
Edward I. ≈øucceeded to the crown, 1272.
Edward II. who was the fir≈øt king of England's ≈øon to whom the title of Prince of Wales was given, began to reign 1307.
Edward III. ≈øucceeded 1327.
Edward, the Black Prince, ≈øon of Edward III. was the fir≈øt in England who a≈ø≈øumed the title of Duke, brought the king of France pri≈øoner to England, 1356.
Richard II. ≈øon of Edward the Black prince, ≈øucceeded his grandfather 1377.
Henry IV. grand≈øon of Edward III. was crowned October 13, 1399.
Henry V. his ≈øon, ≈øucceeded April 9, 1413.
Henry VI. crowned at Paris, December 17, 1430.
Edward IV. was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter, June 28, 1461.

Edward V. began to reign 1483. He was, however, conveyed to the tower. May 1483, and depo≈øed June 20, following. He was afterwards, together with the Duke of York, his brother, ≈ømothered by his uncle, who ≈øucceeded him, under the name of Richard III.
Richard III. brother to Edward IV. murdered prince Edward, ≈øon of Henry VI. in cool blood, 1471, and afterwards married his widow.
Henry VII. after much blood≈øhed, was crowned king of England, October 30, 1485.

Henry VII. the mo≈øt bloody mon≈øter that ever di≈øgraced royalty, married his brother's widow 1509; began to reign June 24th, 1510; received from the Pope the title of Defender of the Faith, for having written a book again≈øt Luther, 1521; renounced the Pope's authority, and a≈ø≈øumed the title of Head of the Church, 1531; divorced his fir≈øt queen, and married
Anne Bulleyne, May 23, 1533; excommunicated by the Pope, Augu≈øt 30, 1536; put Anne Bulleyne to death, and married Jane Seymour, May 20, 1536, who died ≈øoon after: married Anne, ≈øi≈øter to the Duke of Cleves, December 1539, and divorced her, July 10, 1540; married Catharine Howard, Augu≈øt 8, following, and put her to death February 12. 1543; his la≈øt wife was Catharine Parr. The world got rid of him by his death, January 28, 1547.
Edward VI. his only ≈øon, ≈øucceeded Oct. 12, 1537.

Jane Gray, cou≈øin of Edward VI. proclaimed queen July 6, 1553; ≈øhe was, however, in three days after, depo≈øed and beheaded, together with her hu≈øband, Lord Dudley, and her father, February 12 following, by the order of
Mary, who was proclaimed queen July 9, 1553; and died November 17, 1558. She was ≈øucceeded by her half ≈øi≈øter
Elizabeth, who commenced her reign November 17, 1558; ≈øhe beheaded Mary queen of Scotland, February 8, 1587; died March 24, 1603, and was ≈øucceeded by
James VI. of Scotland, who was the great grand≈øon of Henry VII. and I. of the Stuart family in England. He died March 27, 1625, and was ≈øucceeded by his ≈øon

Charles I. who having con≈øpired again≈øt the liberties of his country, was brought to trial January 20, 1649, condemned on the 27th, and beheaded on the 30th following, when the Commonwealth commenced, which might be ≈øaid to terminate on the commencement of the Protectorate of
Oliver Cromwell, who was made Protector for life, December 12, 1653. September 3, 1658, and was ≈øucceeded by his ≈øon
Richard Cromwell, who was proclaimed protector September 4, 1658; depo≈øed, April 22, 1659, when he retired from the bu≈øtle of public life, and lived in quiet till he attained the age of 89.
Charles II. ≈øon of Charles I. was crowned, April 13, 1661; died February 6, 1685; when he was ≈øucceeded by his brother

James II. On June 11, 1685, the Duke of Monmouth, the natural ≈øon of Charles II. landed in England, and was proclaimed king in Somer≈øet≈øhire, June 20th following: he was defeated by James's army, July 5, and beheaded on the 15th following. James left England December 23, 1688, and was ≈øucceeded by his ≈øon-in-law
William III. Prince of Orange, who was declared king, February 13, 1689; he died March 8, 1702, and was ≈øucceeded by his ≈øi≈øter-in-law
Anne, who was crowned April 13, 1704; ≈øhe died, Augu≈øt 1, 1714, and was ≈øucceeded by
George I. Elector of Hanover, who died June 11, 1727.
George II. the ≈øon of George I. began his reign, June 11, 1727, died October 25, 1760, and was ≈øucceeded by the pre≈øent king,
George III. the ≈øon of Frederic, prince of Wales, and grand≈øon of George II.

div.head: KINGS OF SCOTLAND FROM THE YEAR 968.
div.p: James VI. on the death of Elizabeth, queen of England, a≈øcended that throne in 1603, and his de≈øcendants were the kings of England al≈øo till 1707, when the two kingdoms were united under the title of Great Britain.

div.head: KINGS OF FRANCE FROM THE YEAR 987.
div.p: Lewis XVI. the la≈øt king of France, ≈øucceeded his grandfather 1770: he was beheaded January 23, 1793.

div.p: ADULTERY, puni≈øhed in England by public whipping, cutting off the no≈øe and ears, &c. 1031; an act pa≈ø≈øed in England for making this crime capital for the fir≈øt offence, and fornication capital for the ≈øecond, May 14, 1650. Soon after a law was pa≈ø≈øed in New England, by which adultery with a married woman was made capital to both parties, even though the man was unmarried, and ≈øeveral have ≈øuffered under this law.
America, the United States of, declared indepentent, July 4, 1776.
Birds ne≈øts, the de≈øtroying them, forbidden in Sacred Writ, Deut. 22, 6.
Burial, the fir≈øt idea of, was ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken by Adam, on his ob≈øerving a live crow covering a dead one with leaves.
Burning of the dead, in practice 1225 B. C.
Bu≈øhes of evergreen were anciently ≈øigns of taverns, hence the expre≈ø≈øion "good wine needs no bu≈øh."
Caps fir≈øt worn 1449; a law was enacted in England, that every per≈øon ≈øhould wear a cap made of wool on Sundays and holidays, under a con≈øiderable penalty; 1571.
Chri≈øtmas-boxes, were originally for money collected in a box for ma≈ø≈øes.
Coventry, Lady Godvia rode through the town naked, 1057.
Cu≈øtom, according to the Engli≈øh law, is binding when it can be traced back 40 years, in eccle≈øia≈øtical matters, and 60 with re≈øpect to civil matters.
Death, ≈øudden, con≈øidered in France as a mark of infamy, and proof of damnation, 1280.

Diamonds, the nine of, called the cur≈øe of Scotland, from a Scotch member of parliament (part of
who≈øe family arms was the nine of diamonds) voting for the introduction of the malt tax into Scotland.
Don, the title of, fir≈øt a≈ø≈øumed by kings of Spain in the 8th century.
Executions at London, removed from Tyburn to Newgate 1783. Tyburn had been the place of execution for upwards of 650 years.
Fau≈øtus, or Fau≈øt, one of the earlie≈øt printers, who, from concealing his art, was ≈øuppo≈øed to deal with the devil; hence the common expre≈ø≈øion, "the devil and Doctor Fau≈øtus."
Grace before and after meat is a very ancient practice, even in the heathen world.
Harpies, mentioned in the ancient poems, ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome to be locu≈øts: Buffon thinks they were batts, and Bryant thinks they were intended for a college of prie≈øts.
Healths, the cu≈øtom of drinking, was in fa≈øhion ≈øo early as 1134 B. C.
Highlanders, the Scotch, their dre≈øs prohibited by act of parliament, 1746. (That ≈øtatue, we believe, however, has been ≈øince repealed.)
Hocus pocus derived from the≈øe Latin words "Hoe e≈øt corpus."
Ho≈øpitality, in England, appears, for ≈øome centuries previous to the 15th, to have been enforced by ≈øtatue.

Hurley-burley, the expre≈ø≈øion of, is ≈øaid to have derived its origin from Hurleigh and Burleigh, two neighbouring families, who filled the country round about where they lived with conte≈øt and violence.
Jury, trial by, introduced fir≈øt into Denmark about 820; e≈øtabli≈øhed in England 970; and in France, in criminal ca≈øes, 1793.
Literature was ≈øo little known in Britain, from almo≈øt the 9th to the 14th century, that few men, either in church or ≈øtate, could read or write.
Merry Andrew, the character of, aro≈øe from one Andrew Forde, a droll phy≈øician, who attended markets, and in a humourous manner harangued the people, 1547.
Millenium, the doctrine of the, fir≈øt inculcated during the third century.

Mu≈øeum, the mo≈øt valuable collection of the ≈øubjects of natural hi≈øtory to be met with in America, is kept by Mr. Peale in the city of Philadelphia. The utility of this in≈øtitution is con≈øtantly becoming more and more exten≈øive, from the frequent additions which the indefatigable efforts and per≈øeverance of Mr. Peale is con≈øtantly making. There is al≈øo a mu≈øeum of con≈øiderable importance e≈øtabli≈øhed by the Tamany ≈øociety, or Columbian order of New York.
Polygamy forbid by the Romans, 393.
Pre≈ø≈øing, either for the ≈øea or land ≈øervice, declared to be illegal by the Briti≈øh parliament, December 1641.
Pri≈øoners of war, the cu≈øtom of en≈ølaving them, aboli≈øhed in Europe in the 13th century.

Prophet, one Brothers, who pretends to be "the nephew of the Almighty," has given ≈øo great unea≈øine≈øs to the Briti≈øh nation, as to occa≈øion his examination before the Lord Chancellor, in the pre≈øent year 1795.
Receipts, in Britain, ordered to be on ≈øtamped paper, 1783.
Rizzia, a mu≈øician, paramour of Mary queen of Scots, killed by her hu≈øband Lord Darnley, March 9, 1556.
Salute, of other nations to a Briti≈øh ≈øhip of war, was fir≈øt enjoined by king Arthur.
Self murder was fa≈øhionable, among≈øt the Romans, in the reign of Tiberius, when numbers put them≈øelves to death to avoid the per≈øecution of the emperors.
Shrove Tue≈øday, the cu≈øtom of eating pancakes on, probably aro≈øe from the Greek Chri≈øtians eating eggs, milk, &c. on the fir≈øt week of lent.
Slavery commenced immediately after the deluge (≈øee Gene≈øis ix. 25.)

Slaves obtained their freedom in England by act of parliament, 1772. The ≈ølave trade aboli≈øhed in Poli≈øh Pru≈ø≈øia, June 26, 1782; in Penn≈øylvania, 1784; in
Ma≈ø≈øachu≈ø≈øetts, 1788. The propriety of aboli≈øhing this infernal traffic was debated in the Briti≈øh parliament, 1789, and again at different periods. The trade was totally aboli≈øhed in the dominions of the French republic, 1793. An act was pa≈ø≈øed by Congre≈øs, prohibiting the citizens of the United States, or foreigners re≈øiding therein, from carrying on the ≈ølave trade, March 22, 1794.
Theft, in the time of Homer, was reckoned honourable. Lycurgus, the Spartan legi≈ølator, even encouraged it.
Treaties, commercial, the fir≈øt made by England with any foreign nation was with the Flemings, 1272.
Treaties, American, the mo≈øt remarkable,
‚Äî with France, Feb. 6, 1778.
‚Äî with Holland, Oct. 8, 1782.
‚Äî definitive, with Britain, laid before Congre≈øs Dec. 13, 1783, and ratified Jan, 4, 1784.
‚Äî of amity and Commerce with Sweden, April 3, 1783.
‚Äî of amity with the Creek Indians, Augu≈øt 1790.
‚Äî of peace and friend≈øhip with the Cherokee Indians, July 2, 1791.
‚Äî of amity, commerce, and navigation with Britain, November 1794.This treaty is not yet ratified, but is at pre≈øent, June 1795, under con≈øideration of the Senate of the United States.
We, fir≈øt u≈øed in≈øtead of I, by king John of England, 1199.
